common stock.

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<!-- link1 "PART I" -->
<DIV align="left"><A NAME="001"></A></DIV>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>PART I</B>
</FONT>

<!-- link2 "ITEM 1. BUSINESS" -->
<DIV align="left"><A NAME="002"></A></DIV>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>ITEM 1. BUSINESS</B>
</FONT>

<!-- link3 "General" -->
<DIV align="left"><A NAME="003"></A></DIV>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>General</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Pfizer Inc. (which may be referred to as <I>Pfizer, the Company, we</I>, <I>us </I>or
<I>our</I>) is a research-based, global pharmaceutical company. We discover, develop,
manufacture and market leading prescription medicines for humans and animals as
well as many of the world&#146;s best-known over-the-counter products.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company was incorporated under the laws of the State of Delaware on
June&nbsp;2, 1942.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In July 2002, we entered into an agreement to acquire Pharmacia
Corporation. See <I>Proposed Acquisition of Pharmacia Corporation </I>below.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In late 2002 and early 2003, we sold the Tetra fish-care products business
and entered into agreements to sell the Adams confectionery products business
and the Schick-Wilkinson Sword shaving products business, all of which formerly
were part of our Consumer Products segment. In early 2003, we also entered into
an agreement to sell certain of our women&#146;s health product lines (<I>femhrt</I>
hormone-replacement therapy and <I>Loestrin </I>and <I>Estrostep </I>contraceptives), which
formerly were part of our Pharmaceutical segment. All of these divested or
to-be-divested businesses and product lines are reflected as discontinued
operations in our consolidated financial statements for 2002, 2001 and 2000 and
in this 2002 Form&nbsp;10-K. See <I>Discontinued Operations </I>below.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On June&nbsp;19, 2000, we completed our merger with Warner-Lambert Company
(Warner-Lambert). We issued approximately 2.44&nbsp;billion shares of common stock
in exchange for all the outstanding common stock of Warner-Lambert. The merger
qualified as a tax-free reorganization and was accounted for as a pooling of
interests. We restated all consolidated financial statements of Pfizer for
periods prior to the merger to include the results of operations, financial
position and cash flows of Warner-Lambert as if we had always been merged.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Pfizer Website</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K, Quarterly Reports on Form&nbsp;10-Q, Current
Reports on Form&nbsp;8-K and amendments to those reports filed or furnished pursuant
to Section&nbsp;13(a) or 15(d) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 are available
on our website (www.pfizer.com under the &#147;Who We Are &#151; For Investors &#151; SEC
Filings&#148; captions) as soon as reasonably practicable after we electronically
file such material with, or furnish it to, the Securities and Exchange
Commission (SEC).
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Throughout this 2002 Form&nbsp;10-K, we &#147;incorporate by reference&#148; certain
information from parts of other documents filed with the SEC, including our
Annual Report to Shareholders for 2002 (2002 Annual Report) and our proxy
statement for the 2003 Annual Meeting of Shareholders. The SEC allows us to
disclose important information by referring to it in that manner. Please refer
to such information. Portions of our 2002 Annual Report are filed as exhibit 13
to this 2002 Form&nbsp;10-K. Our 2002 Annual Report and our proxy statement for the
2003 Annual Meeting of Shareholders are available on our website
(www.pfizer.com); the 2002 Annual Report is set forth under the &#147;Who We Are &#151; For
Investors &#151; Financial Reports&#148; captions, and the proxy statement is set forth
under the &#147;Who We Are &#151; For Investors &#151; SEC Filings&#148; captions.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Information relating to corporate governance at Pfizer, including our
Corporate Governance Principles; Director Qualification Standards; Chief
Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer certifications; Business Conduct
Policies; and information concerning our Directors, Board Committees, including
Committee charters, and transactions in Pfizer securities by Directors and
officers, is available on our website at www.pfizer.com under the &#147;Who We Are &#151;
For Investors &#151; Corporate Governance&#148; captions. Information relating to
shareholder services, including our Shareholder Investment Program, book-entry
share ownership and direct deposit of dividends, is available on our website at
www.pfizer.com under the &#147;Who We Are &#151; For Investors &#151; Shareholder Services&#148;
captions.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">1</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>


<!-- link3 "Business Segments" -->
<DIV align="left"><A NAME="004"></A></DIV>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Business Segments</B>
</FONT>

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">We operate in two business segments:</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2"><B>Pharmaceutical</B>, which includes</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">-</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">prescription pharmaceuticals for the treatment of cardiovascular
diseases, infectious diseases, central nervous system disorders,
diabetes, arthritis, urogenital conditions, allergies and other
disorders;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">-</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">products for livestock and companion animals; and</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">-</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">the manufacture of empty soft-gelatin capsules.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2"><B>Consumer Products</B>, which includes self-medications for oral
care, upper respiratory health, eye care, skin care,
gastrointestinal health and other products.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Comparative segment revenues, profits and related financial information
for 2002, 2001 and 2000 are presented in the table captioned <I>Segment </I>in Note 21
to our consolidated financial statements, <I>Segment, Geographic and Revenue
Information, </I>on page 65 of our 2002 Annual Report. Tables captioned <I>Percentage
Change in Revenues </I>and <I>Percentage Change in Geographic Revenues </I>on page 31 of
our 2002 Annual Report present additional segment information. The information
from those sections of our 2002 Annual Report is incorporated by reference in
this 2002 Form&nbsp;10-K.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our businesses are heavily regulated in most of the countries where we
operate. In the U.S., the main regulatory authority we deal with is the Food
and Drug Administration (FDA). The FDA regulates the safety and efficacy of the
products we offer, our research quality, our manufacturing processes and our
promotion and advertising. Similar government authorities exist in most other
countries, and in many cases also regulate our prices. See <I>Government
Regulation and Price Constraints </I>below.
</FONT>
<!-- link3 "Pharmaceutical Segment" -->
<DIV align="left"><A NAME="005"></A></DIV>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Pharmaceutical Segment</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our Pharmaceutical segment includes our human pharmaceutical and animal
health businesses, as well as Capsugel, a capsule- manufacturing business.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Human Pharmaceutical</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Most of our human pharmaceutical revenues come from products in three
major therapeutic classes: cardiovascular diseases, infectious diseases and
central nervous system disorders. We also have products for the treatment of
diabetes, urogenital conditions, allergies and other disorders, as well as
copromoted products for arthritis, acute pain and menstrual pain. In 2002,
human pharmaceutical revenues increased 12%, to $28.3&nbsp;billion. Human
pharmaceutical revenues contributed 87% of our revenues in each of 2002 and
2001 and 86% in 2000. We marketed ten human pharmaceutical products, including
our copromoted products <I>Celebrex </I>and <I>Aricept</I>, with sales to third parties
exceeding $1&nbsp;billion each in 2002. Those ten products &#151; <I>Lipitor</I>, <I>Norvasc</I>,
<I>Zoloft</I>, <I>Neurontin</I>, <I>Celebrex, Viagra</I>, <I>Zithromax</I>, <I>Zyrtec</I>, <I>Diflucan </I>and <I>Aricept</I> &#151;
represented 85% of human pharmaceutical revenues and grew at a combined rate of
15% in 2002. A table captioned <I>Revenues &#151; Major Human Pharmaceutical Products</I>
on page 31 of our 2002 Annual Report is incorporated by reference.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cardiovascular disease products that treat problems affecting the heart
and the blood circulatory system make up our largest therapeutic product line.
<I>Lipitor</I>, our largest-selling product, is for treatment of high lipids
(cholesterol and triglycerides) in the bloodstream. It is the largest-selling
prescription drug of any kind in the world. In 2002, the FDA approved two new
starting doses of <I>Liptor</I>, enabling physicians to better tailor therapy
individually across a broad range of patients. <I>Norvasc </I>is a once-a-day
medication for hypertension (high blood pressure) and angina (heart pain). It
is the largest-selling high blood pressure and heart pain medicine in the
world. Our other cardiovascular products include <I>Cardura </I>and
<I>Accupril/Accuretic</I>. <I>Cardura </I>is used to treat hypertension and benign prostatic
hyperplasia (enlarged prostate gland). <I>Accupril/Accuretic </I>is an angiotensin
converting enzyme (ACE)&nbsp;inhibitor for hypertension and congestive heart
failure.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the infectious disease medicine category, our major products include
<I>Zithromax</I>, <I>Diflucan </I>and <I>Viracept</I>. <I>Zithromax, </I>an oral or injectable antibiotic,
is the second-largest-selling antibiotic worldwide and the most-prescribed,
brand-name, oral antibiotic in the U.S. In 2002, we launched the
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">2</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>


<P align="left"><FONT size="2"> new <I>Zithromax Tri-Pak </I>dosage form, the first and only three-day regimen
for the treatment of acute bacterial exacerbations of chronic obstructive
pulmonary disease. <I>Zithromax </I>is licensed exclusively to us by Pliva, a Croatian
pharmaceutical company. <I>Diflucan </I>is the world&#146;s leading systemic antifungal. It
is used to treat various fungal infections, including vaginal infections and
certain infections that afflict HIV/AIDS and cancer patients with weakened
immune systems. Complementing <I>Diflucan </I>is <I>Vfend</I>, a treatment that can be
administered orally or intravenously for certain serious and potentially fatal
fungal infections. <I>Vfend </I>was launched in the U.S. in July 2002 and in Europe
during the latter part of the year. <I>Viracept </I>is the largest-selling protease
inhibitor in the U.S., used in combination with other antiretroviral drugs for
treatment of HIV/AIDS infections. We market <I>Viracept </I>in the U.S. and
Canada.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our major products for treatment of central nervous system disorders
include <I>Zoloft</I>, <I>Neurontin </I>and <I>Geodon </I>and the copromoted product <I>Aricept</I>.
<I>Zoloft </I>is the most-prescribed selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor in the
U.S. and a leading medicine worldwide for the treatment of depression, panic
disorder, obsessive/compulsive disorder, post-traumatic stress disorder,
premenstrual dysphoric disorder, and acute and long-term treatment for social
anxiety disorder (for which it was approved in February 2003). <I>Neurontin </I>is a
leading epilepsy medicine, approved as an add-on therapy with other
anti-epileptic medications to treat partial seizures in patients over three
years of age. It also is approved in more than 60 markets for the treatment of
neuropathic pain. In 2002, <I>Neurontin </I>became the first oral medication approved
in the U.S. to treat post-herpetic neuralgia, a persistent, painful condition
that afflicts many people in the aftermath of shingles. <I>Geodon </I>(known as <I>Zeldox</I>
in many markets outside the U.S.) is for the treatment of symptoms associated
with schizophrenia. In 2002, we launched an intramuscular formulation of
<I>Geodon</I>, used to treat agitated or hospitalized patients, in the U.S. <I>Aricept</I>,
discovered and developed by Eisai Co., Ltd., is the world&#146;s leading medicine to
treat symptoms of Alzheimer&#146;s disease. We copromote <I>Aricept </I>with Eisai in the
U.S. and several other countries and have an exclusive license to sell the drug
in various other countries. Our other products for central nervous system
disorders include <I>Relpax </I>and the copromoted product <I>Rebif</I>. <I>Relpax</I>, an oral
treatment for acute migraine headaches, is marketed throughout Europe and in
Japan. It was approved in the U.S. in December 2002 and launched in the U.S.
during the first quarter of 2003. <I>Rebif, </I>discovered and developed by Serono
S.A., is used to treat symptoms of relapsing forms of multiple sclerosis. In
2002, we entered into an agreement with Serono to copromote <I>Rebif </I>in the U.S.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Viagra</I>, our medication for the treatment of erectile dysfunction, is the
most widely prescribed medication in the world for the treatment of this
condition.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We copromote two medicines for the treatment of arthritis and certain
other conditions, <I>Celebrex </I>and <I>Bextra</I>, with Pharmacia Corporation, which
discovered and developed the drugs. <I>Celebrex </I>is used for the treatment of
rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis, acute pain, menstrual pain and familial
adenomatous polyposis. <I>Bextra </I>was launched in the U.S. in 2002 for the
treatment of rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis and menstrual pain. During
2002, regulatory authorities adopted a positive opinion for granting market
authorization for <I>Bextra </I>in the European Union and, subject to receiving final
approval, launch is planned in Europe for 2003.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Zyrtec </I>is used for the treatment of year-round indoor and seasonal outdoor
allergies and hives. It is indicated for use in children as young as six months
old. <I>Zyrtec </I>syrup is the most-prescribed antihistamine syrup in the U.S., and
<I>Zyrtec-D 12 Hour </I>is the only prescription oral antihistamine/decongestant
combination medicine approved to treat both year-round indoor and outdoor
allergies as well as nasal congestion. <I>Zyrtec </I>is licensed to us by the Belgian
company UCB S.A. We copromote <I>Zyrtec </I>as a prescription medicine in the U.S.
with a subsidiary of UCB S.A., and we have a license to sell <I>Zyrtec </I>as an
over-the-counter (OTC)&nbsp;medicine in Canada, Europe, Australia and South Africa.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Glucotrol XL </I>is used to treat diabetes. It is an oral medicine that
stimulates the pancreas to produce more insulin.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Spiriva </I>is used to treat chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), a
respiratory disorder
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">3</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>


<P align="left"><FONT size="2"> that includes chronic bronchitis and emphysema. We copromote <I>Spiriva </I>with
Boehringer Ingelheim, which discovered and developed the drug. It was launched
in Europe in 2002 and in Canada in January 2003. In December 2002, <I>Spiriva</I>
received an approvable letter from the FDA for the long-term, once-daily
maintenance treatment of bronchospasm associated with COPD.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Animal Health</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our Animal Health business discovers, develops and sells
products for the prevention and treatment of diseases in livestock and
companion animals. Animal Health revenues accounted for 4% of our revenues
in each of 2002, 2001 and 2000. In 2002, Animal Health
revenues increased 10%, to $1.1&nbsp;billion.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Among the products we market are parasiticides, anti-inflammatories,
vaccines, antibiotics and related medicines for livestock and companion
animals, including the products discussed below.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Parasiticides constitute the largest segment of the companion animal
market, consisting mainly of medicines for external parasites, such as fleas,
and heartworm preventatives. Our product <I>Revolution </I>is the first FDA-approved
topical medicine that protects against fleas and heartworm in a simple,
once-a-month administration.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Rimadyl </I>relieves pain and inflammation associated with osteoarthritis, a
condition that afflicts about 20% of adult dogs. <I>Rimadyl </I>is the only arthritis
pain medication prescribed by veterinarians available in chewable tablets as
well as regular caplets.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>RespiSure/Stellamune </I>is a single-dose vaccine used to treat pneumonia in
swine.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Dectomax </I>injectable and pour-on formulations remove and control internal
and external parasites in beef cattle.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Capsugel</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Capsugel is the world&#146;s largest producer of two-piece capsules used in
manufacturing prescription and OTC pharmaceuticals and nutritional supplements.
Capsugel&#146;s sales accounted for about 1% of our revenues in each of 2002, 2001
and 2000. In 2002, Capsugel&#146;s revenues increased 6%, to $436&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
<!-- link3 "Consumer Products Segment" -->
<DIV align="left"><A NAME="006"></A></DIV>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Consumer Products Segment</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our Consumer Products segment consists of our Consumer Healthcare business
(CHC), one of the world&#146;s largest suppliers of OTC medicines.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;CHC markets many of the world&#146;s best-known consumer healthcare brands. Sales
of CHC accounted for 8% of our revenues in each of 2002 and 2001 and 9% of our
revenues in 2000. In 2002, revenues of CHC increased 7%, to $2.5&nbsp;billion.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;CHC&#146;s products compete primarily in the oral care, upper respiratory
health, eye care, skin care and gastrointestinal health categories. CHC&#146;s
principal products include:

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;CHC can extend the life of some of our prescription medications by
converting them to OTC medications. For example, an OTC formulation of
<I>Diflucan</I>, known as <I>Diflucan One</I>, is sold in the U.K. as a treatment for vaginal
candidiasis. Similarly, <I>Zyrtec </I>is sold as an OTC product in certain markets
outside the U.S. As market conditions permit, and when we have necessary
approval from drug regulatory authorities, we plan to pursue similar launches
for other products.

<DIV align="left"><A NAME="007"></A></DIV>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Discontinued Operations</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We sold or are in the process of selling the following businesses and
product lines that do not fit our strategic goals:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">In December 2002, we sold the Tetra fish-care products business, formerly
part of our Consumer Products segment, for $238.5&nbsp;million in cash.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

confectionery products business, formerly part of our Consumer Products
segment, for $4.2&nbsp;billion in cash.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>

segment, for $930&nbsp;million in cash.</FONT></TD>

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">In March 2003, we entered into an agreement to sell certain of our
women&#146;s health product lines (<I>femhrt </I>hormone-replacement therapy and
<I>Loestrin </I>and <I>Estrostep </I>contraceptives), formerly part of our
Pharmaceutical segment. The sale price is $359&nbsp;million in cash, with an
additional cash payment of up to $125&nbsp;million contingent on <I>femhrt </I>and
<I>Estrostep </I>retaining market exclusivity until the expiration of their
respective patents.</FONT></TD>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The divestitures of the Adams and Schick-Wilkinson Sword businesses and
the women&#146;s health product lines are expected to close in the first half of
2003 and are subject to the usual regulatory approvals.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Certain financial information relating to these divested or to-be-divested
businesses and product lines is set forth in Note 4 to our consolidated
financial statements, <I>Discontinued Operations</I>, on page 51 of our 2002 Annual
Report. That information is incorporated by reference.
</FONT>
<!-- link3 "Research and Product Development" -->
<DIV align="left"><A NAME="008"></A></DIV>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Research and Product Development</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Innovation by our research and development operations is very important to
the Company&#146;s success. Our goal is to discover, develop and bring to market
innovative products that address major unmet medical needs. This goal has been
supported by our substantial research and development investments. We spent
$5.2&nbsp;billion in 2002, $4.8&nbsp;billion in 2001 and $4.4&nbsp;billion in 2000 on research
and development.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We conduct research internally, and also through contracts with third
parties, through collaborations with universities and biotechnology companies
and in cooperation with other pharmaceutical firms. We also seek out innovative
technologies developed by third parties to acquire or incorporate into our
discovery or development processes or projects as well as our product lines through licensing or other arrangements.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Drug
discovery and development is time consuming, expensive and unpredictable. On
average, only one out of many thousands of chemical compounds discovered by
researchers proves to be both medically effective and safe enough to become an
approved medicine. The process from discovery to development to regulatory approval can take
more than ten years. Drug candidates can fail at any stage of the process.
Candidates may not receive regulatory approval even after many years of
research.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We believe that our investments in research have been rewarded by the
number of pharmaceutical compounds and new therapies we have in all stages of
development; we currently are working on more than 160 projects in development
and several hundred projects in discovery research. In recent years, our discovery
scientists have delivered dozens of new chemical compounds to early
development. While these new candidates may or may not eventually receive
regulatory approval, new drug candidates entering development are the foundation for future
products.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition to discovering and developing new products, our research
operations add value to our existing products by improving their effectiveness
and by discovering new uses for them. In February 2003, for example, the FDA
approved the additional use of <I>Zoloft </I>for the treatment of social anxiety
disorder.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Information concerning several of our drug candidates in development as
well as supplemental filings for existing products is set forth under the
heading <I>Product Developments </I>on pages 33 and 34 of our 2002 Annual Report. That
information is incorporated by reference. In February 2003, we
submitted an application to the European Medicines Evaluation Agency
for approval of our developmental compound <I>pregabalin</I> for the
treatment of neuropathic pain and for use with other medications in
the treatment of epilepsy. We expect to submit an application to the
FDA for the use of <I>pregabalin</I> for those conditions, as well as
for generalized anxiety disorder, later this year.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our competitors also devote substantial funds and resources to research
and development. In addition, the consolidation that has occurred in our
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">5</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"> industry has created companies with substantial research and development
resources. The extent to which our competitors are successful in their research
could result in erosion of the sales of our products and unanticipated product
obsolescence.
</FONT>
<!-- link3 "International Operations" -->
<DIV align="left"><A NAME="009"></A></DIV>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>International Operations</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have significant operations outside the United States. They are
conducted both through our subsidiaries and through distributors, and involve
the same business segments &#151; pharmaceutical and consumer products &#151; as our U.S.
operations.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Revenues from operations outside the U.S. of $11.6&nbsp;billion accounted for
35.9% of our total revenues in 2002. Revenues exceeded $500&nbsp;million in each of
seven countries outside the U.S. in 2002. No single country outside the U.S.
contributed more than 10% of our total revenues. Japan is our second-largest
national market, with 6.1% of our revenues in 2002, 6.2% in 2001 and 6.6% in
2000.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For a geographic breakdown of revenues and changes in revenues, see the
table captioned <I>Geographic </I>in Note 21 to our consolidated financial statements,
<I>Segment, Geographic and Revenue Information, </I>on page 65 of our 2002 Annual
Report and the table captioned <I>Percentage Change in Geographic Revenues </I>on page
31 of our 2002 Annual Report. Those tables are incorporated by reference.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our international businesses are subject, in varying degrees, to a number
of risks inherent in carrying on business in other countries. These include
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;currency fluctuations
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;capital and exchange control regulations
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;expropriation and nationalization
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;other restrictive government actions
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Our international businesses are also subject to government-imposed
constraints, including laws on pricing or reimbursement for use of products.
See <I>Government Regulation and Price Constraints </I>below for discussion of these
matters.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depending on the direction of change relative to the U.S. dollar, foreign
currency values can increase or reduce the reported dollar value of our net
assets and results of operations. In 2002, foreign exchange had a nominal
impact on revenues. While we cannot predict with certainty future changes in
foreign exchange rates or the effect they will have on us, we attempt to
mitigate their impact through operational means and by using various financial
instruments. See the discussion under Note 6-D to our consolidated financial
statements, <I>Derivative Financial Instruments and Hedging Activities</I>, on pages
53 and 54 of our 2002 Annual Report. That discussion is incorporated by
reference. Related information about valuation and risks associated with such
financial instruments in parts E and F of that same Note is also incorporated
by reference.
</FONT>
<!-- link3 "Marketing" -->
<DIV align="left"><A NAME="010"></A></DIV>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Marketing</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In our global pharmaceutical business, we promote our products to health
care providers such as doctors, nurse practitioners, physician assistants,
pharmacists, hospitals, Pharmacy Benefit Managers (PBMs), Managed Care
Organizations (MCOs) and government agencies. We also market directly to
consumers in the United States through direct-to-consumer print and television
advertising. In addition, we sponsor general advertising to educate the public
about our innovative medical research.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our operations include several pharmaceutical sales organizations. Each
sales organization markets a distinct group of products. Our prescription
pharmaceutical products are sold principally to wholesalers, but we also sell
directly to retailers, hospitals, clinics, government agencies and pharmacies.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Through our marketing organizations, we explain the approved uses and
advantages of our products to medical professionals. We work to gain access to
health authority, PBM and MCO formularies (lists of recommended or approved
medicines and other products) and reimbursement lists by demonstrating the
qualities and treatment benefits of our products. We also work with MCOs and
PBMs to assist them with disease management, patient education and other tools
that help their medical treatment routines. For example, we sponsor a program
offered by the State of Florida Agency for Health Care Administration that is
designed to help manage chronic diseases among Florida&#146;s Medicaid population.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">6</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Marketing of prescription pharmaceuticals depends to a degree on complex
decisions about the scope of clinical trials made years before product
approval. All drugs must complete clinical trials required by regulatory
authorities to show they are safe and effective for treating one or more
medical problems. A manufacturer may choose, however, to undertake additional
studies, including comparative clinical trials with competitive products, to
demonstrate additional advantages of a compound. Those studies can be costly
and take years to complete, and the results are uncertain. Balancing these
considerations makes it difficult to decide whether and when to undertake such
additional studies. But, when they are successful, such studies can have a
major impact on approved marketing claims and strategies.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Separate sales organizations are used by our Animal Health business to
promote its products. Its advertising and promotion are generally targeted to
health professionals, directly and through medical journals. Animal health and
nutrition products are sold through veterinarians, drug wholesalers,
distributors and retail outlets as well as directly to users. Where
appropriate, these products are also marketed through print and television
advertising.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our CHC business primarily uses its own representatives to directly
promote its products. We also use print and television consumer advertising and
offer sales incentives such as coupons to promote our consumer products. These
products are sold through various retailers. CHC also markets and advertises
certain products directly to professionals using a professional detail force.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2002, sales to our three largest pharmaceutical and consumer
healthcare products wholesalers were as follows:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">McKesson, Inc. &#151; 16.8% of our revenues;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">AmerisourceBergen Corporation &#151; 14.8% of our revenues; and</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Cardinal Health, Inc. &#151; 13.4% of our revenues.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Sales to these wholesalers were concentrated in the Pharmaceutical
segment. Apart from these instances, neither of our business segments is dependent
on any one customer or group of related customers.
</FONT>
<!-- link3 "Patents and Intellectual Property Rights" -->
<DIV align="left"><A NAME="011"></A></DIV>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Patents and Intellectual Property Rights</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our products are sold around the world under brand-name, logo and certain
product design trademarks that we consider in the aggregate to be of material
importance. Trademark protection continues in some countries for as long as the
mark is used and, in other countries, for as long as it is registered.
Registrations generally are for fixed, but renewable, terms.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We own or license a number of U.S. and foreign patents. These patents
cover
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">pharmaceutical and other products and their uses</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">pharmaceutical formulations</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">product manufacturing processes</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">intermediate chemical compounds used in manufacturing</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Patents for individual products extend for varying periods according to
the date of patent filing or grant and the legal term of patents in the various
countries where patent protection is obtained. The actual protection afforded
by a patent, which can vary from country to country, depends upon the type of
patent, the scope of its coverage and the availability of legal remedies in the
country.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the aggregate, our patent and related rights are of material importance
to our businesses in the United States and most other countries. Based on
current product sales, and considering the vigorous competition with products
sold by others, the patent rights we consider significant in relation to our
business as a whole, together with the year in which the basic U.S. patent
expires (including, where applicable, the additional six-month pediatric
exclusivity period), are those for the following drugs:
</FONT>

</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In some instances, there are later-expiring patents relating to these
products directed to particular forms or compositions of the drug or to methods
of manufacturing or using the drug in the treatment of further diseases or
conditions. Such patents may not protect the Company&#146;s drug from generic drug
competition after the expiration of the basic patent.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Zithromax </I>is patented by Pliva, a Croatian pharmaceutical company. The
drug is licensed exclusively to us by Pliva for sales and marketing in major
countries, and we purchase the compound in bulk crude form from Pliva.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Celebrex </I>is patented by Pharmacia Corporation, with whom we copromote
<I>Celebrex </I>in all world markets except Japan. An action against Pharmacia and the
Company alleging patent infringement with respect to the sale of <I>Celebrex </I>(as
well as <I>Bextra</I>) was dismissed on March&nbsp;5, 2003. The plaintiff in that action
has appealed the decision.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Zyrtec </I>is patented by the Belgian company UCB S.A. and is licensed to us
for sales in the U.S., Canada, Europe, Australia and South Africa. We copromote
<I>Zyrtec </I>as a prescription medicine in the U.S. with a subsidiary of UCB S.A. and
have a license to sell <I>Zyrtec </I>as an OTC medicine in the other markets.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Aricept </I>is patented by Eisai Co., Ltd. We copromote <I>Aricept </I>with Eisai in
the U.S. and several other countries and have an exclusive license to sell the
drug in various other countries.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The basic U.S. patents relating to <I>Neurontin </I>expired in 1994 and 2000.
However, in April 2000, a U.S. patent was granted relating to stable
pharmaceutical compositions of <I>Neurontin </I>containing low levels of lactam
impurity. This patent expires in 2017. Other companies have filed applications
with the FDA seeking approval of products that we believe infringe this patent.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition, other companies have filed applications with the FDA seeking
approval of products that we believe infringe our patents covering, among other
products, <I>Lipitor, Norvasc, Zoloft</I>, <I>Diflucan, Accupril </I>and <I>Procardia XL</I>. In the
case of <I>Zoloft</I>, while generic manufacturers are challenging certain of our
patents, the outcome of these challenges will not affect the timing of generic
competition with this product due to the existence of additional patents.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have other patent rights covering additional products that have lesser
revenues.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The expiration of a product patent or loss of patent protection resulting
from a legal challenge normally results in significant competition from generic
products against the covered product and, particularly in the U.S., can result
in a significant reduction in sales of the pioneer product. In some cases,
however, we can continue to obtain commercial benefits from
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;product manufacturing trade secrets
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;patents on uses for products
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;patents on processes and intermediates for the economical manufacture of the
active ingredients
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;patents for special formulations of the product or delivery mechanisms
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;conversion of the active ingredient to OTC products
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The effect of product patent expiration or loss also depends upon
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;the nature of the market and the position of the product in it
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;the growth of the market
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;the complexities and economics of manufacture of the product
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;the requirements of generic drug laws
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;One of the main limitations on our operations in some countries outside
the U.S. is the lack of effective intellectual property protection of our
products. Under international agreements in recent years, global protection of
intellectual property rights is improving. The General Agreement on Tariffs and
Trade requires participant countries to amend their intellectual property laws
to provide patent protection for pharmaceutical products by the end of a
ten-year transition period. A number
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">8</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>


<P align="left"><FONT size="2"> of countries are doing this. We have experienced significant growth in our
businesses in some of those nations, and our continued business expansion in
those countries depends to a large degree on further patent protection
improvement.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See Item&nbsp;3, <I>Legal Proceedings</I>, below.
</FONT>
<!-- link3 "Competition" -->
<DIV align="left"><A NAME="012"></A></DIV>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Competition</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Competition is intense in all of our businesses and includes many large
and small competitors.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The principal means of competition vary among product categories and
business groups. Technological innovations affecting
</FONT>

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">efficacy</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">safety</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">patients&#146; ease of use</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">cost effectiveness</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<p align="left"><font size="2">are important to success in all of our businesses.</font>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our businesses also focus on unmet medical needs and therapeutic
improvements. Our emphasis on innovation has led to our multi-billion-dollar
research and development investments over the past decade.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our human pharmaceutical business competes with other worldwide
research-based drug companies, many smaller research companies with more
limited therapeutic focus and generic drug manufacturers. Our pharmaceutical
operations are the largest in the world.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In recent years, a comparison of the total cost of medical treatments
using pharmaceuticals versus alternative treatments for the same condition has
become an important basis of competition. MCOs and PBMs look to cost advantages
as well as medical benefits in making their drug formulary decisions.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our pharmaceutical sales and marketing organization is a valuable
competitive asset. Our salespeople&#146;s ability to reach medical professionals
with information about our products helps us respond to competitive efforts and
launch new products.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have a significant presence in the animal health marketplace, but many
other companies offer competitive products. Altogether, there are hundreds of
producers of animal health products throughout the world. The principal methods
of competition vary somewhat depending on the particular product. They include
</FONT>

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">product innovation</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">service</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">price</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>

</TABLE>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We promote our products directly through our sales representatives as well as
through advertising.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Many other companies, large and small, manufacture and sell one or more
products that are similar to our consumer healthcare products. Sources of
competitive advantage include
</FONT>


<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">price</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>


<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Significant expenditures for advertising, promotion and marketing are generally
required to achieve both consumer and trade acceptance of consumer products.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the current environment of competitive pressures on profit margins, we
continue efforts to control the growth of our expenses. We have kept our costs
down in areas such as manufacturing, distribution and sales administration by
restructuring and consolidating facilities. These measures have brought us new
efficiencies and reduced or contained our operating expenses.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Managed Care Organizations</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The growth of MCOs in the U.S. has been a major factor in the competitive
make-up of the health care marketplace. Over half the U.S. population now
participates in some version of managed care. Because of the size of the
patient population covered by MCOs, marketing of prescription drugs to them and
the PBMs that serve many of those organizations has become important to our
business.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;MCOs can include medical insurance companies, medical plan administrators,
health-
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">9</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>


<P align="left"><FONT size="2"> maintenance organizations, alliances of hospitals and physicians and other
physician organizations. The purchasing power of MCOs has been increasing in
recent years due to their growing numbers of enrolled patients. At the same
time, those organizations have been consolidating into fewer, even larger
entities. This enhances their purchasing strength and importance to us.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A major objective of MCOs is to contain and, where possible, reduce health
care expenditures. They typically use formularies, volume purchases and
long-term contracts to negotiate discounts from pharmaceutical providers. They
use their purchasing power to bargain for lower supplier prices. They also
emphasize primary and preventive care, out-patient treatment and procedures
performed at doctors&#146; offices and clinics. Hospitalization and surgery,
typically the most expensive forms of treatment, are carefully managed.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As discussed above in <I>Marketing</I>, MCOs and PBMs typically develop
formularies to reduce their cost for medications. Formularies can be based on
the prices and therapeutic benefits of the available products. Due to their
generally lower cost, generic medicines are often favored. The breadth of the
products covered by formularies can vary considerably from one MCO to another,
and many formularies include alternative and competitive products for treatment
of particular medical problems. MCOs use a variety of means to encourage
patients&#146; use of products listed on their formularies.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Exclusion of a product from a formulary can lead to its sharply reduced
usage in the MCO patient population. Consequently, pharmaceutical companies
compete aggressively to have their products included. Where possible, companies
compete for inclusion based upon unique features of their products, such as
greater efficacy, better patient ease of use or fewer side effects. A lower
overall cost of therapy is also an important factor. Products that demonstrate
fewer therapeutic advantages must compete for inclusion based primarily on
price.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The growth of MCOs also appears to have led to greater usage of some
drugs. The use of certain drugs can prevent the need for more costly treatments
such as hospitalization, professional therapy or even surgery. Because of these
advantages, such drugs can become favored first-line treatments. In addition,
the current trend of some patients to opt for managed care alternatives to
Medicare may increase overall pharmaceutical usage among that segment of the
elderly population. Medicare generally does not pay for outpatient use of
medicines, so patients who do not have another source of prescription drug
coverage must bear that cost. MCOs, however, often offer drug benefits for
their participants.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;These developments not only have created pressure on prices, but also have
increased sales of products on formularies. We have been generally, although
not universally, successful in having our major products included on MCO
formularies.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Another way we address the interests of MCOs is by developing
disease-management programs. These programs can be attractive to MCOs by
improving patient communications and compliance with dosage directions, which
are important for effective disease treatment. They can help MCOs address
various aspects of disease management, such as prevention, diagnosis and
treatment of certain diseases, including use of pharmaceutical products. This
comprehensive approach can improve the quality of care and lower costly
complications of chronic diseases. As noted above in <I>Marketing</I>, one such
program, which is sponsored by us and offered by the State of Florida Agency
for Health Care Administration, is designed to help manage chronic diseases
among Florida&#146;s Medicaid population.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Generic Products</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;One of the biggest competitive challenges that we face in the U.S. and
that is growing internationally is from generic pharmaceutical manufacturers.
Upon the expiration or loss of U.S. patent protection on a product, we can lose
the major portion of U.S. sales of that product in a very short period. Generic
competitors operate without our large research and development expenses and our
costs of conveying medical information about the product to the medical
community. In addition, the FDA approval process exempts generics from costly
and time-consuming clinical trials to demonstrate their safety and efficacy,
and allows generic manufacturers to rely on the safety and efficacy of the
pioneer product. Generic products need only demonstrate a level of
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">10</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>


<P align="left"><FONT size="2"> availability in the bloodstream equivalent to that of the pioneer product.
This means that after we have borne the expenses of discovering, developing and
testing a medicine for safety and efficacy, obtaining regulatory approval and
informing the medical community about its therapeutic benefits, generic
competitors can market a competing version of our product after the expiration
of our patent, charge much less and still be profitable.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As noted above, MCOs that focus primarily on the immediate cost of drugs
often favor generics over brand-name drugs. Many governments also encourage the
use of generics as alternatives to brand-name drugs in their health care
programs, including Medicaid in the U.S. Laws in the U.S. generally allow, and
in some cases require, pharmacists to substitute generic drugs that have been
rated under government procedures to be therapeutically equivalent to a
brand-name drug. The substitution must be made unless the prescribing physician
expressly forbids it.
</FONT>
<!-- link3 "Raw Materials" -->
<DIV align="left"><A NAME="013"></A></DIV>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Raw Materials</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Raw materials essential to our businesses are purchased worldwide in the
ordinary course of business from numerous suppliers. In general, these
materials are available from multiple sources. No serious shortages or delays
were encountered in 2002, and none are expected in 2003.
</FONT>
<!-- link3 "Government Regulation and Price Constraints" -->
<DIV align="left"><A NAME="014"></A></DIV>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Government Regulation and Price Constraints</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Pharmaceutical companies are subject to extensive regulation by numerous
national, state and local agencies. Of particular importance is the FDA in the
United States. It has jurisdiction over virtually all of our businesses and
administers requirements covering the testing, safety, effectiveness,
manufacturing, labeling, marketing, advertising and post-marketing surveillance
of our pharmaceutical products. FDA requirements and/or reviews have increased
the amount of time and money necessary to develop new products and bring them
to market.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The FDA also regulates most of our consumer healthcare products and, along
with the U.S. Department of Agriculture and the U.S. Environmental Protection
Agency, our animal health products.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Since
1998, the approval of new drugs across the European Union (EU) is possible only using
the European Medicines Evaluation Agency&#146;s (EMEA)&nbsp;mutual recognition or central
approval processes. The use of either of these procedures provides a more rapid
and consistent approval within the 15 member states than was the case when the
approval processes were operating independently within each member state.
Further, on January&nbsp;1, 2000, Norway and Iceland became full participants in the
EU central approval processes. In addition, the agreement between the EU and 12
other European states to base their approvals on the centralized EU approval
will significantly speed the regulatory process in those countries. The EMEA
does not have jurisdiction over patient reimbursement or pricing matters in EU
member countries, however. We continue to deal with individual countries on
such issues.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In recent years in the U.S., various legislative proposals have been
offered at the federal and state levels that would bring about major changes in
the affected health care systems. Some states have passed such legislation, and
further federal and state proposals are possible. Such proposals and
legislation include, and future proposals could include, price controls or
patient access constraints on medicines and increases in required rebates or
discounts. Similar issues exist
in many foreign countries where we do business. We cannot predict the outcome
of such initiatives, but we will work to maintain patient access to our
products and to oppose price constraints.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the U.S., federal proposals have called for substantial changes in the
Medicare program, and federal and state proposals have called for substantial
changes in the Medicaid program. Driven by budget concerns, Medicaid access and
reimbursement restrictions have been implemented in some states and proposed in
many others. If the Medicare and Medicaid programs implement changes that
restrict the access of a significant population of patients to our innovative
medicines, our business could be materially affected. On the other hand,
relatively little pharmaceutical use is currently covered by Medicare. If
changes to Medicare shift patients to MCOs that cover
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">11</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>


<P align="left"><FONT size="2"> pharmaceuticals, or if an outpatient drug benefit is added to Medicare,
usage of pharmaceuticals could increase. Pricing pressures likely would ensue
in either case given the enhancement of the purchasing power of the MCOs or the
federal government.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Medicare currently does not generally provide outpatient prescription drug
coverage. In this context, in order to help address the issue of affordable
access to health care for those most in need, we instituted the Pfizer for
Living Share Card program in 2002. Through this program, low-income Medicare
recipients without prescription drug coverage can purchase 30-day prescriptions
of any Pfizer prescription medicine and of the copromoted product <I>Aricept </I>at many retail pharmacies for $15.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;U.S. law requires us to give rebates to state Medicaid agencies based on
each state&#146;s reimbursement of pharmaceutical products under the Medicaid
program. Some states are seeking rebates in excess of the amounts required by
federal law, and there are federal legislative proposals to expand current
Medicaid rebates. We also must give discounts or rebates on purchases or
reimbursements of pharmaceutical products by certain other federal and state
agencies and programs. In 2000 and 2001, the states of Vermont and Maine
received approval of waivers from the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid
Services that would expand Medicaid rebates beyond the current Medicaid
population. Both of these waivers were struck down by federal appeals courts.
Separately, in 2000 the state of Maine passed legislation requiring
pharmaceutical companies to provide the same price discounts to residents of
the state, regardless of their income, who are not eligible for Medicaid as are
provided to Medicaid participants. If a pharmaceutical company declines to
provide such discounts to the non-Medicaid population, in most cases doctors
will not be allowed to prescribe that company&#146;s drugs to Medicaid patients
without obtaining prior authorization from the state. The Maine program was
upheld by a federal appeals court in 2001. That decision has been appealed to
the U.S. Supreme Court, and a decision is expected later this year. If the
Maine program is upheld on appeal, other states may adopt similar legislation
that would extend Medicaid-level discounts beyond the current Medicaid
population.</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Rebates potentially could be viewed as price discounts without
appreciable increases in volume as an offset. See the discussion regarding
rebates on page 32 of our 2002 Annual Report, which discussion is incorporated
by reference.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We encounter similar regulatory and legislative issues in most other
countries. In Europe and some other international markets, the government
provides health care at low direct cost to consumers and regulates
pharmaceutical prices or patient reimbursement levels to control costs for the
government-sponsored health care system. This international patchwork of price
regulation has led to different prices and some third-party trade in our
products from markets with lower prices. Such trade exploiting price
differences between countries can undermine our sales in markets with higher
prices.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In October 2002, the Bush Administration announced a regulatory initiative
relating to patent litigation pursuant to the 1984 Drug Price Competition and
Patent Term Restoration Act, known as the Hatch-Waxman Act. Under the
Hatch-Waxman Act, if a generic drug company files an abbreviated new drug
application (ANDA)&nbsp;with the FDA and a research-based drug company promptly
files a lawsuit alleging that the generic product would infringe one or more of
its patents, approval of the ANDA by the FDA automatically is stayed for a
period of up to 30&nbsp;months. The proposed regulation would permit only one such
30-month stay period to be triggered by a patent-infringement suit between a
research-based firm and an ANDA applicant. The proposed regulation also would
clarify the type of patents eligible for listing in the FDA&#146;s &#147;Orange Book&#148;. A
final FDA regulation is anticipated this year. It also is possible that
legislation amending the Hatch-Waxman Act could be enacted this year. One
possible amendment would codify the Bush Administration&#146;s regulatory initiative
and also require that settlements in patent-challenge cases between
research-based drug companies and generic drug companies be reported to the
Federal Trade Commission. Other proposals that would be detrimental to the
innovative pharmaceutical industry already have been introduced and could be
enacted.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition to the FDA, the U.S. Department of Agriculture and the U.S.
Environmental
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">12</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>


<P align="left"><FONT size="2"> Protection Agency, we are subject to the jurisdiction of various other
regulatory and enforcement departments and agencies, such as the Department of
Health and Human Services, the Federal Trade Commission and the Department of
Justice in the U.S. We are, therefore, subject to possible administrative and
legal proceedings and actions by those regulatory bodies (see Item&nbsp;3, <I>Legal
Proceedings</I>, below). Such actions may include product recalls, seizures and
other civil and criminal sanctions. In some cases, we have initiated product
recalls voluntarily.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;It is difficult to predict the future impact of the broad and expanding
legislative and regulatory requirements affecting us.
</FONT>
<!-- link3 "Environmental Law Compliance" -->
<DIV align="left"><A NAME="015"></A></DIV>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Environmental Law Compliance</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Most of our manufacturing and certain research operations are affected by
federal, state and local environmental laws. We have made, and intend to
continue to make, necessary expenditures for compliance with applicable laws.
We also are cleaning up environmental contamination from past industrial
activity at certain sites (see Item&nbsp;3, <I>Legal Proceedings</I>, below). As a result,
we incurred capital and operational expenditures in 2002 for environmental
protection and clean-up of certain past industrial activity as follows:
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;While we cannot predict with certainty the future costs of such clean-up
activities, capital expenditures or operating costs for environmental
compliance, we do not believe they will have a material effect on our capital
expenditures, earnings or competitive position.
</FONT>
<!-- link3 "Banking and Insurance Subsidiaries" -->
<DIV align="left"><A NAME="016"></A></DIV>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Banking and Insurance Subsidiaries</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We conduct international banking operations through a subsidiary, Pfizer
International Bank Europe (PIBE), based in Dublin, Ireland. PIBE, incorporated
under the laws of Ireland, operates under a banking license from the Central
Bank of Ireland. It makes loans and accepts deposits in several currencies in
international markets. PIBE is an active Euromarket lender to financially
strong borrowers through its portfolio of loans and money market instruments.
Loans are made primarily on a short- and medium-term basis, typically with
floating interest rates.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We also own an insurance operation, The Kodiak Company Limited, which
reinsures certain assets, inland transport and marine cargo of our
international operations.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Financial data for these subsidiaries are set forth in Note 5 to our
consolidated financial statements, <I>Banking and Insurance Subsidiaries</I>, on page
51 of our 2002 Annual Report, and information relating to our banking
operations is set forth under the heading <I>Banking Operation </I>on pages 38 and 39
of our 2002 Annual Report. Such data and information are incorporated by
reference.
</FONT>
