<TR valign="bottom" bgcolor="#eeeeee">
    <TD colspan="2"><DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px"><FONT size="2">SECTION 11.&nbsp;&nbsp;AMENDMENT, SUSPENSION, AND TERMINATION</FONT></DIV></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">15</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</CENTER>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">-ii-</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>SECTION 1. CONTINUATION AND PURPOSE OF THE PLAN.</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;1.1 Continuation. There is hereby continued for the benefit of Members an
unfunded plan of deferred compensation known as the &#147;Pfizer Inc Nonfunded
Deferred Compensation and Supplemental Savings Plan.&#148;
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;1.2 Purpose. The purpose of this Plan is to provide a means by which an
Eligible Employee may, in certain circumstances, elect to defer receipt of a
portion of his &#147;Regular Earnings.&#148; The Plan also provides that the Company
will, in certain instances, credit the Account of a Member with Employer
Accruals.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;1.3 Description of the Plan. The Plan became effective July&nbsp;1, 1983 and
is amended and restated effective February&nbsp;1, 2002, except as otherwise
provided herein. For purposes of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act
of 1974 (&#147;ERISA&#148;), as amended, the Plan shall be treated as two separate,
unfunded plans. One plan shall be an &#147;excess benefit plan&#148; within the meaning
of Section&nbsp;3(36) of ERISA, and shall be comprised of accruals under the Plan
that are made solely because of the applicable limitations under Section&nbsp;415 of
the Code, plus earnings thereon. All other accruals under the Plan, plus
earnings thereon, shall be treated as made under a separate &#147;top-hat&#148; plan
maintained by the Company primarily for the purpose of providing deferred
compensation to a select group of management or highly compensated employees,
within the meanings of Sections&nbsp;201(a)(2) and 401(a)(1) of ERISA. Separate
accounts shall be maintained under the Plan for each Member, as
applicable, to account for excess benefit plan accruals and earnings, and
top-hat plan accruals and earnings.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">-1-</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>SECTION 2. DEFINITIONS</B>.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following words and phrases as used in this Plan have the following means:
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2.1 Account. The term &#147;Account&#148; shall mean a Member&#146;s individual
account(s), as described in Section&nbsp;5 of the Plan.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2.2 Board of Directors. The term &#147;Board of Directors&#148; means the Board of
Directors of the Company.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2.3 Code. The term &#147;Code&#148; means the Internal Revenue Service Code of
1986, as amended.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2.4 Committee. The term &#147;Committee&#148; means the Committee, as described in
the Qualified Plan, or any other person or entity that the Committee has
authorized to act on its behalf under the Plan.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2.5 Company. The term &#147;Company&#148; means Pfizer Inc, a Delaware corporation,
and any successor corporation.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2.6 Controlled Group. The term &#147;Controlled Group&#148; means the Company and
any other entity in which the Company owns directly or indirectly 30&nbsp;percent or
more of the value or voting power.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2.7 Eligible Employee. The term &#147;Eligible Employee&#148; means any &#147;Member&#148;
under the Qualified Plan (i)&nbsp;who receives Regular Earnings for any Plan Year in
excess of the limitation of Section&nbsp;401(a)(17) of the Code, (ii)&nbsp;whose account
under the Qualified Plan is credited with &#147;annual additions,&#148; as defined in
Section&nbsp;415(c)(2) of the Code,
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">-2-</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>


<P align="left"><FONT size="2">during any Plan Year equal to the maximum
permitted under Section&nbsp;415(c)(1)(A) of the Code, (iii)&nbsp;who is otherwise
credited with Employer Accruals, or (iv)&nbsp;who is a member of a select group of
management or highly compensated employees and is designated as an Eligible
Employee by the Committee.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2.8 Employer. The term &#147;Employer&#148; means the Company and any other member
of the Controlled Group which is also an &#147;Associate Company&#148; under the
Qualified Plan.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2.9 Employer Accrual. The term &#147;Employer Accrual&#148; means the amounts
described in Section&nbsp;4.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2.10 Excess Regular Earnings. The term &#147;Excess Regular Earnings&#148; means
(i)&nbsp;the portion of a Member&#146;s Regular Earnings earned during a Plan Year that
exceeds the Limitation on compensation taken into account under Section
401(a)(17) of the Code, (ii)&nbsp;all Regular Earnings earned after the Member
becomes subject to the Limitation on contributions to defined contribution
plans under Section&nbsp;415(c)(1)(A) of the Code, to the extent not included in (i)
above, (iii)&nbsp;a bonus deferred under the Pfizer Inc Deferred Compensation Plan,
or (iv)&nbsp;any other compensation determined by the Committee to be compensation
for purposes of this Plan .
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2.11 Excess Regular Earnings Deferrals. The term &#147;Excess Regular Earnings
Deferrals&#148; means the portion of a Member&#146;s Excess Regular Earnings that the
Member elects to defer under the terms of the Plan.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">-3-</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2.12 Limitation(s). The term &#147;Limitation(s)&#148; means the limitation on
contributions to defined contribution plans under Section&nbsp;415(c)(1)(A) of the
Code, and on compensation taken into account under Section&nbsp;401(a)(17) of the
Code.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2.13 Member. The term Member means an Eligible Employee who elects to
have Excess Regular Earnings Deferrals made to the Plan or is otherwise
credited with an Employer Accrual.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2.14 Payment Options. The term &#147;Payment Option&#148; means the following forms
of payment under which a Member may elect to receive amounts credited to his
Account upon his termination of employment with the Controlled Group: (i)
single sum payable as soon as practicable following the end of the Plan Year in
which the Member terminates employment with the Controlled Group, or (ii)
substantially equal annual installment payments over a period of two to twenty
years commencing as soon as practicable following the end of the Plan Year in
which the Member terminates employment with the Controlled Group. Where
payment of the Account is made in installment payments, the first installment
shall be a fraction of the value of the Member&#146;s Account as of the applicable
valuation date, the numerator of which is one (1)&nbsp;and the denominator of which
is the total number of installments remaining to be
paid at that time. Each subsequent installment shall be calculated in the same
manner, except that the denominator shall be reduced by the number of
installments that have been paid previously.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2.15 Plan. The term &#147;Plan&#148; means the &#147;Pfizer Inc Nonfunded Deferred
Compensation and Supplemental Savings Plan,&#148; as set forth herein and as amended
from time to time.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">-4-</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2.16 Plan Year. The term &#147;Plan Year&#148; means the calendar year.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2.17 Qualified Plan. The term &#147;Qualified Plan&#148; means the Pfizer Savings
Plan, as amended from time to time.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2.18 Regular Earnings. The term &#147;Regular Earnings&#148; shall have the meaning
given such term under the Qualified Plan.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>SECTION 3. PARTICIPATION</B>.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;3.1 Designation of Eligible Employees. The Committee in its sole and
absolute discretion will designate as Eligible Employees those employees who
satisfy the terms of Section&nbsp;2.7 and are eligible to participate in the Plan.
The Committee in its sole and absolute discretion may terminate the designation
of an employee as an Eligible Employee at any time.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;3.2 Election to Make Excess Regular Earnings Deferrals. An Eligible
Employee may elect
at any time after becoming eligible to begin making Excess Regular Earnings
Deferrals by filing an election with the Committee or its authorized designee
in accordance with this Section&nbsp;3 and any rules established by the Committee.
Such election will be effective on a prospective basis beginning with the
payroll period that occurs as soon as administratively practicable following
receipt of the election by the Committee or its authorized designee.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;3.3 Amendment or Suspension of Election. Members may change (including,
suspend) their existing Excess Regular Earnings Deferrals election under this
Plan during the Plan Year by filing a new election in accordance with the
prescribed administrative
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">-5-</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>


<P align="left"><FONT size="2">guidelines. Such new election will be effective on a
prospective basis beginning with the payroll period that occurs as soon as
administratively practicable following receipt of the election by the Committee
or its authorized designee. A Member shall not be permitted to make up
suspended Excess Regular Earnings Deferrals, and during any period in which a
Member&#146;s Excess Regular Earnings Deferrals are suspended, the Employer Accruals
under the Plan with respect to Excess Regular Earnings Deferrals shall also be
suspended. A Member who receives a hardship withdrawal under the Qualified
Plan shall be suspended from making Excess Regular Earnings Deferrals hereunder
for a period of six (6)&nbsp;months from the date of such withdrawal.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;3.4 Amount of Elections. Each election filed by an Eligible Employee must
specify the amount of Excess Regular Earnings Deferrals in a whole percentage
from 1% to 20% of the Member&#146;s Excess Regular Earnings unless the Committee
establishes a lesser percentage for the Plan Year;
provided, however, that, with respect to an Eligible Employee who is also
eligible to participate in the Qualified Plan, the rate of Excess Regular
Earnings Deferrals hereunder for any payroll period shall not exceed the rate
at which the Member was contributing to the Qualified Plan on a combined
pre-tax and post-tax basis for the current year.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">-6-</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>SECTION 4. EMPLOYER ACCRUALS</B>.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;4.1 General Rule.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;An Employer Accrual will be credited to a Member&#146;s Account with respect to
the eligible portion of Excess Regular Earnings Deferrals of such Member at the
applicable rate of &#147;Matching Contributions&#148; with respect to &#147;After-Tax
Contributions&#148; and &#147;Before-Tax Contributions&#148; under the Qualified Plan. The
Employer Accrual shall be credited as soon as practicable following the payroll
period for which the Excess Regular Earnings Deferrals are made. The eligible
portion of a Member&#146;s Excess Regular Earnings Deferrals shall be limited to six
percent (6%) of such Excess Regular Earnings for each payroll period. In
addition, an Employer Accrual will be credited as of the end of each Plan Year
to a Member&#146;s Account equal to the difference between (i)&nbsp;the amount that would
have been credited to the Member&#146;s account under the Qualified Plan as a
&#147;Matching Contribution,&#148; including Additional Contribution, if any, if the
Limitations were not applicable to the Member under the Qualified Plan during
such Plan Year and (ii)&nbsp;the &#147;Matching Contributions,&#148; including Additional
Contributions, if any, actually credited to the Member&#146;s account under the
Qualified Plan during such Plan Year. Lastly, an Employer Accrual will be
credited to the Account of a Member who elects to defer his bonus under the
Warner-Lambert Company Incentive Compensation Plan (&#147;ICP&#148;). The amount of such
Employer Accrual will be equal to the product of: (i)&nbsp;six percent (6%) of the
bonus deferred under the ICP, and (ii)&nbsp;the applicable rate of &#147;Matching
Contributions&#148; with respect to &#147;After-Tax Contributions&#148; and &#147;Before-Tax
Contributions&#148; under the
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">-7-</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>


<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Qualified Plan. The Employer Accrual shall be credited as soon as practical
following the payroll period in which the bonus is deferred.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;4.2 Special Employer Accrual for Certain Former Warner-Lambert Employees.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the case of any Eligible Employee who (i)&nbsp;was an &#147;Eligible Participant&#148;
under the Warner-Lambert Savings and Stock Plan as in effect on January&nbsp;31,
2002 (the &#147;Warner-Lambert Plan&#148;), (ii)&nbsp;is a participant under the
Warner-Lambert Enhanced Severance Plan on May&nbsp;15, 2003, (iii)&nbsp;has completed at
least three years of Plan membership (including Warner-Lambert Plan membership)
under the Qualified Plan as of May&nbsp;15, 2003, and (iv)&nbsp;was an Eligible Employee
on May&nbsp;15, 2003, an Employer Accrual shall be credited to such Eligible
Employee&#146;s Account in an amount equal to the difference between (a)&nbsp;and (b)
below:
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(a)&nbsp;the &#147;Matching Contribution&#148; which would have been made to the Eligible
Employee&#146;s account under the Qualified Plan with respect to the period June&nbsp;1,
2002 through May&nbsp;15, 2003 if such &#147;Matching Contribution&#148; had been based on the
terms of Article&nbsp;5 of the Warner-Lambert Plan, assuming an additional matching
contribution rate of 65%; and
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(b)&nbsp;the &#147;Matching Contribution&#148; actually made to the Eligible Employee&#146;s
account under the Qualified Plan with respect to the period June&nbsp;1, 2002
through May&nbsp;15, 2003.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">This Employer Accrual shall be credited as soon as practicable following the
payroll period which includes May&nbsp;15, 2003.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">-8-</FONT>




<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;4.3&nbsp;Special Employer Accrual for Certain Former Agouron Employees.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the case of any Eligible Employee who (i)&nbsp;was an &#147;Eligible Employee&#148;
under the Agouron Pharmaceuticals, Inc. 401(k) Plan as in effect on January&nbsp;31,
2002 (the &#147;Agouron Plan&#148;), (ii)&nbsp;was a participant under the Warner-Lambert
Enhanced Severance Plan on May&nbsp;15, 2003, and (iii)&nbsp;was an Eligible Employee on
May&nbsp;15, 2003, an Employer Accrual shall be credited to such Eligible Employee&#146;s
Account in an amount equal to the difference between (a)&nbsp;and (b)&nbsp;below:
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(a)&nbsp; the &#147;Matching Contribution&#148; which would have been made to the Eligible
Employee&#146;s account under the Qualified Plan with respect to the period June&nbsp;1,
2002 through May&nbsp;15, 2003 if such &#147;Matching Contribution&#148; had been based on the
terms of Article&nbsp;6.4 of the Agouron Plan, assuming an additional matching
contribution rate of 35%; and
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(b)&nbsp; the &#147;Matching Contribution&#148; actually made to the Eligible Employee&#146;s
Account under the Qualified Plan with respect to the period June&nbsp;1, 2002
through May&nbsp;15, 2003.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">This Employer Accrual shall be credited as soon as practicable following the
payroll period which includes May&nbsp;15, 2003.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>SECTION 5.</B>&nbsp;&nbsp; <B>INDIVIDUAL ACCOUNT</B>.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;5.1&nbsp;Creation of Accounts. The Company will maintain an Account under the
Plan in the name of each Member. Each Member&#146;s Account will be credited with
the amount of the Member&#146;s Excess Regular Earnings Deferrals, Employer
Accruals, and will
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">-&nbsp;9&nbsp;-</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">be adjusted for earnings and losses thereon. In the case of
Members covered under both the &#147;excess benefit&#148; and &#147;top-hat&#148; portions of the
Plan, separate accounts will be maintained to reflect the Members&#146; interest in
each such portion of the Plan.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;5.2&nbsp;Payment Account Option Election. Each Member shall elect the
particular Payment Option that is to apply to amounts credited to the
Member&#146;s Account. In order for a Payment Option election to be effective, it
must be made (i)&nbsp;no later than ninety (90)&nbsp;days (one hundred and eighty (180)
days for employment terminations on or after January&nbsp;1, 2003) prior to the date
the Member terminates employment with the Controlled Group, and (ii)&nbsp;in a
taxable year preceding the taxable year in which payment would otherwise be
made or commence. In the absence of a timely election, payment of the Member&#146;s
Account will be made in accordance with the most recent Payment Option election
which satisfies the requirements of the immediately preceding sentence or, in
the absence of any such Payment Option election, in five (5)&nbsp;substantially
equal annual installments commencing as soon as practicable following the end
of the Plan Year in which the Member terminates employment with the Controlled
Group. The foregoing notwithstanding, in any case where the value of the
Member&#146;s Plan Account is less than ten percent (10%) of the value of the
Member&#146;s interest in both the Plan and the Qualified Plan, payment of the
Member&#146;s Account shall be made in a lump sum as soon as practicable following
the end of the Plan Year in which the Member terminates employment with the
Controlled Group. Upon a Member becoming &#147;Disabled,&#148; as determined under the
Qualified Plan, the balance of the Member&#146;s Account shall be paid in a lump sum
as soon as practicable after such determination is made.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">-&nbsp;10&nbsp;-</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;5.3&nbsp;Investments. All Excess Regular Earnings Deferrals will be credited
with an amount equal to the amount which would have been earned had such
amounts been actually invested in one or more of the &#147;Funds&#148; (other than the
Pfizer Match Fund) available for investment under the Qualified Plan, as the
Member may elect from time to time, in one percent (1%) increments. The
portion of the Member&#146;s Account attributable to Employer Accruals shall be
deemed to be invested in the Pfizer Match Fund. Rules similar to those which
govern the Qualified Plan shall apply for purposes of determining the value of
the deemed investments and the timing, frequency and permissibility of
investment transfers, except that no diversification of Employer Accruals which
are deemed to be invested in the Pfizer Match Fund shall be permitted. No
provision of this Plan shall require the Company or any other Employer to
actually invest any amount in any &#147;Fund&#148; or in any other investment vehicle.
The Plan is an unfunded plan that is not subject to the funding requirements of
ERISA, meaning that there are no actual investments held in a trust. The
Accounts represent unsecured obligations of the Company, and no funds are set
aside from the Company&#146;s general assets to cover such Accounts. The Plan is
subject to the full faith and credit of the Company, and Members would be
general creditors in the event of the Company&#146;s insolvency.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;With respect to a Member subject to Section&nbsp;16 of the Securities Exchange
Act of 1934, an election to transfer a portion of his Account into, or out of,
the &#147;Pfizer Company Stock Fund&#148; shall be permitted only if the Member has not
elected during the immediately preceding six months to transfer out of, or
into, such Fund within this Plan, the Pfizer Company Stock Fund under the
Qualified Plan or the unit account within the Pfizer Inc Nonfunded Deferred
Compensation and Unit Award Plan for Non-Employee Directors,
the</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">-&nbsp;11&nbsp;-</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Pfizer Inc
Retainer Units Award Plan for Non-Employee Directors, or the Pfizer Inc
Deferred Compensation Plan.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>SECTION 6.</B>&nbsp;&nbsp; <B>PAYMENT</B>.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;6.1&nbsp;Payment of Benefits. A Member shall be paid the balance of his
Account following termination of employment in accordance with the Payment
Option elected by the Member. Upon the death of a Member, the Member&#146;s
beneficiary shall be paid the balance of the Member&#146;s Account in a lump sum as
soon as practicable after the death of the Member.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;6.2.&nbsp;Benefits Subject to Withholding. The benefits payable under this
Plan shall be subject to the deduction of any federal, state, or local income
taxes, employment taxes or other taxes which are required to be withheld from
such payments by applicable laws and regulations. Any employment taxes owed by
the Member with respect to any deferral, accrual or benefit payable under this
Plan may be withheld from other compensation of the Member in the year in which
such tax liability accrues.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>SECTION 7.</B>&nbsp;&nbsp; <B>NATURE OF INTEREST OF MEMBER</B>.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Participation in this Plan will not create, in favor of any Member, any
rights or lien in or against any of the assets of the Company or any Employer,
and all amounts of Excess Regular Earnings deferred hereunder shall at all
times remain an unrestricted asset of the Company or the Employer. A Member&#146;s
rights to benefits payable under the Plan are not subject in any manner to
anticipation, alienation, sale, transfer, assignment, pledge, or encumbrance.
Nothing contained in this Plan, and no action taken pursuant to
its</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">-&nbsp;12&nbsp;-</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">provisions,
shall create or be construed to create a trust of any kind, or a fiduciary
relationship, between any Employer and a Member or any person, and the Company&#146;s and each Employer&#146;s
promise to pay benefits hereunder shall at all times remain unfunded as to the
Member.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>SECTION 8.</B>&nbsp;&nbsp; <B>BENEFICIARY DESIGNATION</B>.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A Member&#146;s beneficiary under this Plan will automatically be the same as
such Member&#146;s beneficiary under the Qualified Plan unless a separate
designation of beneficiary form for this Plan has been properly filed with the
Committee or its authorized designee in accordance with any rule established by
the Committee. In the absence of a designation of specific beneficiary under
either the Qualified Plan or this Plan, which beneficiary survives the Member,
upon the Member&#146;s death, payment of his Account shall be made to his estate in
a lump sum as soon as practicable.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>SECTION 9. </B>&nbsp;&nbsp; <B>ADMINISTRATION</B>.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;9.1&nbsp;Committee. This Plan will be administered by the Committee.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;9.2&nbsp;Powers of the Committee. The Committee&#146;s powers under this Plan are
the same as are described in the Qualified Plan and include, but are not
limited to, the power:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">(i)&nbsp;to determine who are Eligible Employees for
purposes of participation in the Plan;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">(ii)&nbsp;to interpret the terms and provisions of the
Plan and to determine any and all questions arising under the
Plan, including without</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">-&nbsp;13&nbsp;-</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>


<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">limitation, the right to remedy
possible ambiguities, inconsistencies, or omissions by a
general rule or particular decision; and</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">(iii)&nbsp;to adopt rules consistent with the Plan.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;9.3&nbsp;Claims Procedure. The Committee shall make, in its sole discretion,
all determinations arising in the administration, construction or
interpretation of the Plan including the right to construe disputed or doubtful
Plan terms and provisions, and any such determination shall be conclusive and
binding on all persons, except as otherwise provided by law. Any claim by a
Member or any other person for any benefit alleged to be due under the Plan
shall be made in writing to the Committee. Within 90&nbsp;days of the filing of
such claim, unless special circumstances require an extension of such period,
such person will be given notice in writing of the approval or denial of the
claims. If the claim is denied, the notice will set forth the reason for the
denial, the Plan provisions on which the denial is based, an explanation of
what other material or information, if any, is needed to perfect the claim, and
an explanation of the claims review procedure. The claimant may request a
review of such denial within 60&nbsp;days of the date of receipt of such denial by
filing notice in writing with the Committee. The claimant will have the right
to review pertinent Plan documents and to submit issues and comments in
writing. The Committee will respond in writing to a request for review within
60&nbsp;days of receiving it, unless special circumstances require an extension of
such period. The Committee, in its discretion, may request a meeting to
clarify any matters deemed appropriate.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;9.4&nbsp;Limitation on Period for Filing Claims. No claim for benefits based
upon a claim that contributions were not properly made under this Plan shall be
approved under
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">-&nbsp;14&nbsp;-</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">this Plan, and no action may be brought for benefits under this
Plan pursuant to the denial of such a claim pursuant to Section&nbsp;9.3 of this
Plan, unless such claim for benefits is duly filed under Section&nbsp;9.3 of this
Plan no later than the last day of the second Plan Year beginning after the
Plan Year in which the claim alleges that the contributions should have been
credited.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>SECTION 10.</B>&nbsp;&nbsp; <B>NO EMPLOYMENT RIGHTS</B>.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;No provisions of the Plan or any action taken by the Company, the Board of
Directors, the Committee, or any of their properly authorized representatives
shall give any person any right to be retained in the employ of any Employer,
and the right and power of the Company or any Employer to dismiss or discharge
any Member is specifically reserved.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>SECTION 11. AMENDMENT, SUSPENSION, AND TERMINATION</B>.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Board of Directors or its authorized designee shall have the rights to
amend, suspend, or terminate the Plan at any time, except that the Committee
may make non-substantive administrative changes to this Plan so as to conform
with or take advantage of governmental requirements, statutes or regulations.
No amendment, modification or termination shall, without the consent of a
Member, adversely affect the amount of the Member&#146;s benefits in his or her
Account as of the date of such amendment, modification or termination. Any
modification, amendment or termination may accelerate the time at which any
Member is entitled to a distribution. In the event the Plan is terminated, the
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">-&nbsp;15&nbsp;-</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Committee shall continue to administer the Plan in accordance with the relevant
provisions thereof until the Member&#146;s benefits have been paid hereunder.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">-&nbsp;16&nbsp;-</FONT>

All financial data for 2002, 2001 and 2000 reflect our confectionery, shaving
and fish-care products businesses as well as certain women's health product
lines as discontinued operations. We have not restated periods prior to 2000 for
these discontinued operations because the data are not available. After we
reorganized our financial systems due to the merger with Warner-Lambert Company,
the level of detail necessary to develop financial information for these
discontinued operations for periods prior to 2000 was no longer available.

           factor in our leases, which are not material.

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<DIV align="right"><FONT size="2">Exhibit&nbsp;13</FONT></DIV>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>Financial Review<BR>
PFIZER INC AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>OVERVIEW OF CONSOLIDATED OPERATING RESULTS</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">In 2002, total revenues grew 12% to $32,373&nbsp;million. Our human pharmaceutical
business drove our performance, achieving revenue growth of 12% in 2002. We
market or copromote ten human pharmaceutical products that each generated sales
to third parties of $1&nbsp;billion or more in 2002. Net income grew 17% to $9,126
million and diluted earnings per common share (EPS)&nbsp;grew 20% to $1.46 in 2002
as compared to the prior year. Net income was impacted by:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">non-cash charges for impairment provisions related to goodwill and
identifiable intangible assets, which reduced net income by $410&nbsp;million after
tax as a result of the January&nbsp;1, 2002 adoption of Statement of Financial
Accounting Standards No.&nbsp;142, Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets &#151; such
charges are recorded as a cumulative effect of a change in accounting
principle;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">costs related to our 2000 merger with Warner-Lambert Company
(Warner-Lambert), which reduced net income by $331&nbsp;million after tax in 2002 as
compared to $505&nbsp;million after tax in 2001 &#151; such costs included integration
costs and restructuring charges;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">pre-integration costs related to our proposed acquisition of Pharmacia
Corporation (Pharmacia), which reduced 2002 net income by $59&nbsp;million after
tax; and</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">certain significant items, which were a net increase to 2002 net income of
$13&nbsp;million after tax &#151; such items included the gain on the sale of a
discontinued business, gains on the sales of product lines, copromotion
charges, asset impairment charges, charges to write-down equity investments,
charges for various litigation matters, and merger-related costs of the
confectionery, shaving, and fish-care products businesses, which were
discontinued in 2002.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We sold or are in the process of selling the following businesses and product
lines that do not fit our strategic goals:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Tetra fish-care products business (sold in December 2002)</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Adams confectionery products business</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Schick-Wilkinson Sword shaving products business</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">certain women&#146;s health product lines &#151; femhrt hormone replacement therapy
and Loestrin and Estrostep contraceptives</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The divestitures of the Adams and Schick-Wilkinson Sword businesses and the
women&#146;s health product lines are expected to close in the first half of 2003.
These businesses and product lines are reflected as discontinued operations in
2002, 2001 and 2000.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">In 2001, total revenues grew 11% to $29,024&nbsp;million. Our human pharmaceutical
business drove our performance, achieving revenue growth of 13% in 2001. Eight
human pharmaceutical products that we marketed or copromoted each generated
sales to third parties of $1&nbsp;billion or more in 2001. Net income grew 109% to
$7,788&nbsp;million and diluted EPS grew 107% to $1.22 in 2001 as compared to the
prior year. These results were impacted by:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">negative effects of foreign exchange, which reduced 2001 revenues by $742
million;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">costs related to our 2000 merger with Warner-Lambert, which reduced net
income by $505&nbsp;million after tax in 2001 as compared to $2,773&nbsp;million after
tax in 2000 &#151; such costs included integration costs and restructuring charges;
and</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">certain significant items, which were a net reduction to net income of $58
million after tax &#151; such items included an increase to revenues from an
accounting harmonization for Medicaid discounts and contract rebate accruals,
gains on the sales of equity investments, copromotion charges, and
merger-related costs of the confectionery, shaving and fish-care products
businesses, which were discontinued in 2002.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The following accounting policies are important to an understanding of our
operating results and financial condition and should be considered an integral
part of the financial review. For additional accounting policies, see note 1 to
the consolidated financial statements, &#147;Significant Accounting Policies.&#148;
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Estimates and Assumptions</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">In preparing our financial information, we use some estimates and assumptions
that may affect reported amounts and disclosures. Estimates are used when
accounting for sales discounts, allowances and incentives, depreciation,
amortization, employee benefits, contingencies and asset valuations. For
instance, in determining our annual pension and other post-employment benefit
costs, we estimate the rate of return on plan assets and the cost of future
health care benefits. We are also subject to risks and uncertainties that may
cause actual results to differ from estimated results, such as changes in the
health care environment, competition, foreign exchange, litigation, legislation
and regulations. Certain of these risks, uncertainties and assumptions are
discussed under the heading &#147;Forward-Looking Information and Factors That May
Affect Future Results.&#148;
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Sales Recognition</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>REVENUE RECOGNITION </B>&#151; We record revenue from product sales when the goods are
shipped and title passes to the customer.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>SALES INCENTIVES </B>&#151;We generally record sales incentives as a reduction of
revenue at the time the related revenue is recorded or when the incentive is
offered, whichever is later. We estimate the cost of sales incentives based on
our historical experience with similar incentive programs.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>SALES DISCOUNTS AND REBATES
</B>&#151; Provisions for discounts and rebates to customers
are recorded based on the terms of sale in the same period the related sales
are recorded. We determine the provision for Medicaid discounts and contract
rebates based on an estimate of reimbursable prescriptions filled for
individuals covered by Medicaid or a provider with whom we contract.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Alliances</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We have agreements to promote pharmaceutical products discovered by other
companies. Revenue is earned when our copromotion partners ship the related
products and title passes to their customer. Our alliance revenue is primarily
based upon a percentage of our copromotion partners&#146; net sales. Generally,
expenses for selling and marketing these products are included in
<I>Selling,
informational and administrative (SI&#038;A) expenses</I>.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Prior to the copromoted product receiving regulatory approval, we expense, as
incurred, milestone payments made under these agreements and record them in
Other (income)/deductions &#151; net. Once the product receives regulatory approval,
we record any subsequent milestone payments in Other assets, deferred taxes and
deferred charges and amortize them over the remaining license term or the
expected product life cycle, whichever is shorter. On an ongoing basis, we
review for impairment those milestone payments that have been recorded as
assets.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">ANNUAL REPORT 2002
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">P28</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>



<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>Financial Review<BR>
PFIZER INC AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Research and Development Expenses</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Research and development (R&#038;D) costs are expensed as incurred. These expenses
include the cost of our proprietary R&#038;D efforts as well as costs incurred in
connection with our third-party collaboration efforts. Pre-approval
milestone payments made by us to third parties under contracted R&#038;D
arrangements are expensed when the specific milestone has been achieved. We
have no third-party R&#038;D arrangements that result in the recognition of revenue.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Contingencies</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We and certain of our subsidiaries are involved in various patent, product
liability, consumer, commercial, environmental, and tax litigations and claims;
government investigations; and other legal proceedings that arise from time to
time in the ordinary course of our business. We record accruals for such
contingencies based upon our assessment that the occurrence is probable, and
where determinable, an estimate of the liability amount. We consider many
factors in making these assessments, including past history, scientific
evidence and the specifics of each matter. However, litigation is inherently
unpredictable and excessive verdicts do occur. We record anticipated recoveries
under existing insurance contracts when assured of recovery. We also provide
tax reserves when we believe that a taxing authority is likely to take a
sustainable position on a matter contrary to the position taken by us or one of
our subsidiaries when filing required tax returns.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Financial Instruments</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We invest, borrow and offset or hedge through a variety of financial
instruments.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Held-to-maturity debt securities are reported at cost, which reflects our
intent and ability to hold the securities until maturity and to redeem the
securities for their face value.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Available-for-sale debt securities are reported at estimated fair value, with
changes in fair value reported as an increase or decrease in Shareholders&#146;
equity. These are liquid investments and their fair values are based on a
valuation model that uses observable market quotes and credit ratings of the
securities.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Accounts receivable are reported at contract value, less our estimate for
uncollectible amounts based on our experience relative to the total population
of accounts receivable.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">All derivative contracts are reported at estimated fair value, with changes in
fair value reported in earnings or deferred until the offset or hedged item is
recognized in earnings, depending on the nature and effectiveness of the offset
or hedging relationship (where changes in the fair value of the hedged item are
counterbalanced by changes in the fair value of the derivative hedging
instrument). The fair values of these contracts are based on valuation models
that use observable market quotes and our view of the creditworthiness of the
derivative counterparty. Any ineffectiveness in a hedging relationship is
recognized immediately into earnings. Ineffectiveness is minimized through the
proper relationship of the hedging derivative contract with the hedged item.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Pension Plans</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We maintain pension plans in the U.S. and abroad in accordance with local laws
and regulations. In 2002, we made voluntary contributions in excess of minimum
requirements of $610&nbsp;million to our pension plans in major markets. In the
U.S., we have established qualified defined benefit pension plans in accordance
with the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, as amended. We have
traditionally contributed the maximum allowed by the Internal Revenue Service &#151;
an amount significantly above government-mandated minimum funding requirements.
Our U.S. qualified defined benefit pension plans have been well funded
historically. The recent decline in the equity markets coupled with the decline
in long-term interest rates has not caused our U.S. qualified defined benefit
pension plans to require government-mandated funding. Given our strong cash
flow generation, we fully expect to be able to meet any potential future
pension funding obligations.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We also provide benefits through supplemental (non-qualified) retirement plans
to certain employees. We provide for these plans out of our general assets
since these plans are not generally funded.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Our assumption for the expected long-term rate of return on assets in our U.S.
pension plans to determine net periodic benefit cost is 9% for 2003, which
represents a 1% decline from our 2002 rate of return of 10%. The assumption for
the expected return on assets reflects our long-term outlook for equity and
fixed income returns, factoring in our pension plans&#146; historical annualized
compound return in excess of 9% and our asset allocation and investment
strategy as well as our financial modeling around long-term market
expectations. The expected return is applied to the fair market value of plan
assets at each year-end. As a sensitivity measure, the effect of a 1% decline
in the return-on-assets assumption is an increase in our 2003 U.S. (pre-tax)
pension expense of approximately $30&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The discount rate used in calculating our U.S. pension benefit obligations at
December&nbsp;31, 2002 is 6.9%, which represents a 0.4% decline from our December
31, 2001 rate of 7.3%. The December&nbsp;31, 2002 discount rate represents the
weighted average of the plans&#146; respective discount rates. The discount rate is
largely based upon an index of high-quality fixed income investments (U.S.
Moody&#146;s AA Long-Term Corporate Bond Index ) at the plans&#146; respective
measurement dates. As a sensitivity measure, the effect of a 0.4% decline in
the discount rate assumption is an increase in our 2003 U.S. (pre-tax) pension
expense of approximately $31&nbsp;million and an increase in the U.S. pension plans&#146;
projected benefit obligations at December&nbsp;31, 2002 of approximately $240
million.
</FONT>

<P align="right"><FONT size="2">ANNUAL REPORT 2002</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">P29</FONT>

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">(74</FONT></TD>
    <TD nowrap><FONT size="2">)</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD colspan="2"><DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></DIV></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><HR size="1" noshade></TD>

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Certain reclassifications were made in 2001 and 2000 to conform to the 2002
presentation.<BR>
Percentages in this table and throughout the financial review may reflect
rounding adjustments.</FONT></TD>

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">* Calculation not meaningful.</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>REVENUES</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Revenues increased 12% to $32,373&nbsp;million in 2002 and 11% to $29,024&nbsp;million in
2001. Revenue increases in both years were due to newly launched products, new
indications for existing products and sales volume growth of our human
pharmaceutical products.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Revenues in the U.S. grew 11% to $20,762&nbsp;million in 2002 and 13% to $18,629
million in 2001. International revenues grew 12% to $11,611&nbsp;million in 2002 and
8% to $10,395&nbsp;million in 2001.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Revenues exceeded $500&nbsp;million in each of seven countries outside the U.S. in
2002 and in each of six countries outside the U.S. in 2001. The U.S. was the
only country to contribute more than 10% of total revenues in both years.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">In the second quarter of 2001, we brought the accounting methodology pertaining
to accruals for estimated liabilities related to Medicaid discounts and
contract rebates of Warner-Lambert into conformity with our historical method.
At Warner-Lambert, the amount of the liability was determined based on a
historical percentage of sales. The adjustment reversed the cumulative effect
of several years of applying different methodologies. The adjustment increased
Revenues in 2001 by $175&nbsp;million. There were no cash or operational changes,
nor were our Medicaid or managed-care-contract partners affected as a result of
this adjustment.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>ELEMENTS OF TOTAL REVENUE GROWTH (PERCENTAGES)</B>
</FONT>

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

</TABLE>

</TR>

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;* Currency impact was negligible in 2002.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>REVENUES BY BUSINESS SEGMENT</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We operate in the following two business segments:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2"><B>PHARMACEUTICAL </B>&#151; including:</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<CENTER>
<TABLE cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="90%">
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="96%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&#150;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">
treatments for cardiovascular diseases, infectious diseases, central
nervous system disorders, diabetes, arthritis, urogenital conditions and
allergies, as well as the manufacture of empty soft-gelatin capsules</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&#150;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">
products for livestock and companion animals</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B>&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;CONSUMER PRODUCTS </B>&#151; including self-medications for:
</FONT>
<CENTER>
<TABLE cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="90%">
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="96%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&#150;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">
oral care, upper respiratory health, eye care, skin care and
gastrointestinal health</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>TOTAL REVENUES BY BUSINESS SEGMENT</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>PHARMACEUTICAL</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The pharmaceutical segment includes our human pharmaceutical and animal health
businesses as well as Capsugel, a capsule manufacturing business. Revenues of
our pharmaceutical segment were as follows:
</FONT>
<CENTER>
<TABLE cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="39%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="4%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="4%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="4%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>HUMAN PHARMACEUTICAL</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">In the U.S. market, human pharmaceutical revenue growth was 12% in 2002 and 14%
in 2001. International growth was 12% in 2002 and 11% in 2001. Excluding the
effect of the 2001 harmonization of an accounting methodology for Medicaid
discounts and contract rebate accruals, human pharmaceutical revenue grew by
13% in 2002. On this same basis, but also excluding the impact of foreign
exchange, human pharmaceutical revenue grew by 15% in 2001.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">In 2002, ten human pharmaceutical products that we market or copromote each
achieved sales to third parties of $1&nbsp;billion or more. These products &#151;Lipitor,
Norvasc, Zoloft, Neurontin, Celebrex, Zithromax, Viagra, Diflucan, Zyrtec and
Aricept &#151; representing 85% of our human pharmaceutical revenues, grew at a
combined rate of 15% in 2002.
</FONT>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2"><B>Lipitor </B>is the largest-selling statin medicine worldwide for the treatment
of elevated cholesterol levels in the blood.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2"><B>Norvasc </B>is the world&#146;s most-prescribed branded medicine for treating
hypertension.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2"><B>Zithromax </B>is the most-prescribed brand-name oral antibiotic in the U.S.
and the second-largest-selling antibiotic worldwide.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2"><B>Diflucan&#146;s </B>sales growth after 14&nbsp;years on the market reflects the
product&#146;s continuing acceptance as the therapy of choice for a wide range
of fungal infections.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2"><B>Zoloft </B>is the most-prescribed selective serotonin re-uptake inhibitor in
the U.S. for the treatment of depression, obsessive-compulsive disorder
(in adults and children), panic disorder, post-traumatic stress disorder
(in adults) and premenstrual dysphoric disorder.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2"><B>Neurontin </B>is the world&#146;s top-selling anticonvulsant for use in adjunctive
therapy for epilepsy. Neurontin is also approved in more than 60 markets
for the treatment of neuropathic pain conditions. Neurontin is the first
oral medication approved in the U.S. to treat post-herpetic neuralgia
(pain caused by a viral infection and producing a condition commonly known
as shingles).</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2"><B>Viagra, </B>for the treatment of erectile dysfunction, is among the most
widely prescribed medications in the world.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2"><B>Zyrtec </B>provides strong, rapid and long-lasting relief for seasonal and
year-round allergies and hives with once-daily dosing. Zyrtec-D 12 Hour
prescription oral antihistamine decongestant combination</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="right"><FONT size="2">ANNUAL REPORT 2002</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>Financial Review<BR>
PFIZER INC AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">medicine that treats both indoor and outdoor allergies, as well as nasal congestion.
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Alliance revenue reflects revenue associated with our copromotion of Celebrex, Bextra, Aricept, Spiriva and Rebif.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<CENTER>
<TABLE cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="90%">
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="96%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">-</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">
<B>Celebrex</B>, the first Cox 2 specific inhibitor to enter the market and currently the best-selling arthritis treatment worldwide was discovered and developed by our alliance partner Pharmacia.</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">-</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">
<B>Bextra</B>, the latest entry to the Cox 2 specific inhibitor market was also discovered and developed by our alliance partner Pharmacia. With Celebrex and Bextra, we can offer physicians a broad, extensive
portfolio enabling them to treat a wide range of conditions from rheumatoid arthritis, to osteoarthritis, to primary dysmenorrhea (menstrual pain in adults).</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">-</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">
<B>Aricept</B>, discovered and developed by our alliance partner Eisai Co., Ltd., is the world&#146;s leading medicine to treat symptoms of Alzheimer&#146;s disease.</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">-</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">
<B>Spiriva</B>, discovered and developed by our alliance partner Boehringer Ingelheim, is used to treat chronic obstructive pulmonary disease &#151; a chronic respiratory disorder that includes chronic bronchitis and
emphysema.</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">-</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">
<B>Rebif</B>, discovered and developed by Serono S. A. (Serono), is used to treat symptoms of relapsing forms of multiple sclerosis.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</CENTER>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Pharmacia&#146;s worldwide sales of Celebrex decreased 2% to $3,050&nbsp;million in 2002 and increased 19% to $3,114&nbsp;million in 2001. Pharmacia&#146;s worldwide sales of Bextra were $470&nbsp;million in 2002.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Alliances allow us to copromote or license these products for sale in certain countries. Under the copromotion agreements, these products are marketed and promoted with our alliance partners. We provide cash,
staff and other resources to sell, market, promote and further develop these products.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Rebates under Medicaid and related state programs reduced revenues by $570&nbsp;million in 2002, $342&nbsp;million in 2001 ($403&nbsp;million excluding the effect of the harmonization of the Pfizer/Warner-Lambert accounting
methodology for Medicaid discount accruals) and $349&nbsp;million in 2000. We also provided legislatively mandated discounts to the U.S. federal government of $420&nbsp;million in 2002, $343&nbsp;million in 2001 and $237&nbsp;million
in 2000. Performance-based contracts also provide for rebates to several customers. These contracts are with managed care customers, including health maintenance organizations and pharmacy benefit managers, who
receive rebates based on the achievement of contracted performance terms for products. Rebates are product specific, and therefore, for any given year can be impacted by the mix of products sold.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Companion animal product revenues increased 14% in 2002 driven by strong global
performance that was well-balanced across key brand performance as follows:
</FONT>

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Rimadyl (for relief of arthritis pain in dogs) sales grew 14% due to
increased field and marketing emphasis on the brand throughout our
international markets and increased veterinary demand in the U.S. based on
a new U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA)&nbsp;approval for a postoperative
pain indication</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Revolution (for protection against fleas and heartworm) sales grew 35%
largely due to benefits generated from increased promotional efforts in
Europe and a change from distributorship to direct customer sales in one
of our Asian markets</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Clavamox/Synulox (an antibiotic for dogs and cats) sales grew 21% due to
field and marketing emphasis on the brand throughout our
markets</font></td>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">partially offset by:</FONT>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">our companion animal vaccine line, which showed growth of 5%, reflective
of a mature market segment in which our commitment to customer service
enables us to maintain our customer base</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Livestock product revenues increased 6% in 2002 with key performance as follows:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">swine vaccine sales grew 18% due to the 2002 launch of Flusure (a swine
influenza vaccine) in the U.S., as well as the launch of RespiSure One/
Stellamune One (a single-dose swine vaccine to prevent pneumonia) in our
international markets</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">cattle vaccine sales grew 12% due to growth in our European markets, where
the livestock market has shown signs of recovery, and in Latin America,
resulting from higher sales of vaccines for foot-and-mouth disease</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">partially offset by:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Dectomax (a treatment for internal and external parasites in cattle and
swine) sales, which remained flat, as the product faced increased generic
competition and price erosion throughout our markets</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">ANNUAL REPORT 2002
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">P32</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>Financial Review<BR>
PFIZER INC AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Animal health revenues decreased 3% in 2001 primarily due to:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">the impact of mad-cow disease and foot-and-mouth disease in Europe</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">the negative effects of foreign exchange (animal health revenues increased
2% in 2001 excluding the impact of foreign exchange)</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">partially offset by:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">increased sales of Revolution</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">new promotional and distribution practices as well as various
restructuring initiatives</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Excluding the impact of foreign exchange and the feed-additive product lines
which were sold in November 2000, animal health revenues increased 13% in 2001.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">In November 2000, we sold animal health&#146;s feed-additive product lines to Phibro
Animal Health, a wholly owned subsidiary of Philipp Brothers Chemicals, Inc.,
for cash of $45&nbsp;million and a promissory note for $23&nbsp;million due March&nbsp;1, 2004.
The sale resulted in a loss of $85&nbsp;million, which was recorded
in <I>Other
(income)/deductions&nbsp;&#151; net</I>.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>CONSUMER PRODUCTS</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The consumer products segment consists of our consumer healthcare business, a
supplier of over-the-counter medicines.
</FONT>

    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="7"><FONT size="1"><B>% CHANGE</B></FONT></TD>
</TR>

    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The 7% increase in consumer healthcare revenues in 2002 was primarily due to:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">the success of Listerine PocketPaks representing 5% of the 7% overall
increase in consumer healthcare revenues</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">the 10% increase in sales of Listerine mouthwash</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The 4% increase in consumer healthcare revenues in 2001 was primarily due to:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">the sales growth of Sudafed, Benadryl and Listerine mouthwash</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">the U.S. launch of Listerine PocketPaks in September 2001</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>PRODUCT DEVELOPMENTS</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We continue to invest in R&#038;D to provide future sources of revenue through the
development of new products, as well as through additional uses for existing
in-line and alliance products. We have six new products that were recently
approved or are undergoing regulatory review in the U.S. and/or European Union
(E.U.): Bextra (discovered and developed by Pharmacia), Spiriva (discovered and
developed by Boehringer Ingelheim), Vfend, Geodon, Relpax and Rebif (discovered
and developed by Serono).We intend to launch all six products in new markets
once regulatory approvals are received. However, there are no assurances as to
when, or if, we will receive regulatory approval for these or any of our other
new products.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Certain significant regulatory actions by, and filings pending with, the FDA
follow:
</FONT>

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">In December 2002, Spiriva received an approvable letter from the FDA for the
long-term once-daily maintenance treatment of bronchospasm associated with
COPD. The E.U. Mutual Recognition procedure was completed in April 2002.
Spiriva is commercially available in 13 countries, including Germany,
Canada and the United Kingdom.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">In November 2002, the FDA approved revised labeling for Bextra to include
a contraindication for use in patients who have demonstrated allergic-type
reactions to sulfonamides, statements in the &#147;warnings&#148; section regarding
serious skin and anaphylactoid reactions and information in the
post-marketing experience section about hypersensitivity and skin
reactions.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">In October 2002 and September 2002, the intravenous formulations of
Zithromax were approved in Spain and Italy.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="right"><FONT size="2">ANNUAL REPORT 2002</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">P33</FONT>
