<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">*</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Included in <I>Other current liabilities.</I></FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Through December&nbsp;31, 2002, the charges for
employee termination costs represent the
approved reduction of our work force of our
continuing businesses by 7,961 people,
mainly in administrative functions for
corporate, manufacturing, distribution,
sales and research. We notified affected
individuals, and as of December&nbsp;31, 2002,
7,321 employees had been terminated.
Employee termination costs include accrued
severance benefits and costs associated
with change-in-control provisions of
certain Warner-Lambert employment
contracts. Under the terms of these
contracts, certain terminated employees may
elect to defer receipt of severance
benefits. Severance benefits deferred for
future payments were $218&nbsp;million at
December&nbsp;31, 2002 and $215&nbsp;million at
December&nbsp;31, 2001. The deferred severance
benefits are considered utilized charges
and are included in <I>Other noncurrent
liabilities</I>.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The impairment and disposal charges through
December&nbsp;31, 2002 for property, plant and
equipment include the consolidation of
facilities and related fixed assets and the
termination of certain software
installation projects.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">ANNUAL REPORT 2002</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">P 50</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>


<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements<BR>
PFIZER INC AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>4.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;DISCONTINUED OPERATIONS</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We sold or are in the process of selling
the following businesses and product lines
that do not fit our strategic goals:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">In December 2002, we sold our Tetra
fish-care products business, formerly part
of our Consumer Products segment to the
Triton Fund, for $238.5&nbsp;million in cash. We
recognized a gain of $117&nbsp;million ($77
million net of tax) on the sale in 2002.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">In December 2002, we entered into an
agreement to sell the Adams confectionery
products business, formerly part of our
Consumer Products segment, to Cadbury
Schweppes plc for $4.2&nbsp;billion in cash.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">In January 2003, we entered into an
agreement to sell the Schick-Wilkinson
Sword shaving products business, formerly
part of our Consumer Products segment, to
Energizer Holdings Inc. for $930&nbsp;million in
cash.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">We decided to sell certain of our women&#146;s
health product lines (femhrt, Loestrin and
Estrostep), formerly part of our
Pharmaceutical segment.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The divestitures of the Adams and
Schick-Wilkinson Sword businesses and the
women&#146;s health product lines are expected
to close in the first half of 2003 and are
subject to the usual regulatory approvals.
These businesses and product lines are
reflected as discontinued operations in
2002, 2001 and 2000.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>6.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>A.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investments in Debt and Equity Securities</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">In 2002, we reclassified substantially all
of our held-to-maturity debt securities to
available-for-sale debt securities. The
amortized cost of the securities
reclassified was $13,839&nbsp;million and the
unrealized gain on such securities was
immaterial. We review the key
characteristics of our debt securities
portfolio on at least a quarterly basis.
Upon completion of this review, we
reclassified the securities because we no
longer had the positive intent to hold such
securities to maturity. As a result of this
decision, any debt security that we may
purchase over a two-year period, which
began July&nbsp;1, 2002, will not be classified
as held-to-maturity.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">P 51</FONT>

<P align="right"><FONT size="2">ANNUAL REPORT 2002</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements<BR>
PFIZER INC AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Information about our investments follows:
</FONT>
<CENTER>
<TABLE cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="75%">

</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>B.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Short-Term Borrowings</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The weighted average effective interest
rate on short-term borrowings outstanding
at December&nbsp;31 was 1.7% in 2002 and 2.4% in
2001. At December&nbsp;31, 2002, we had
approximately $2.9&nbsp;billion of lines of
credit that expire within one year. Of
these lines of credit, $2.5&nbsp;billion are
unused, of which our lenders have committed
to loan us $500&nbsp;million at our request.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>C.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Long-Term Debt</B>
</FONT>

    <TD width="4%">&nbsp;</TD>

<P>
<HR size="1" width="18%" align="left" noshade>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">*</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Includes unrealized gains and
losses for debt with fair value
hedges in 2002 and 2001 (see note
6-D, &#147;Financial Instruments
&#151; Derivative Financial Instruments
and Hedging Activities&#148;).</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The floating-rate unsecured notes bear
interest at a defined variable rate based
on the commercial paper borrowing rate. The
weighted average interest rate of these
notes was 1.5% at December&nbsp;31, 2002 and
2.1% at December&nbsp;31, 2001. These notes
minimize credit risk on certain
available-for-sale debt securities that may
be used to satisfy the notes at maturity.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">In 2002, we issued $600&nbsp;million of senior
unsecured notes, which pay interest
annually, in arrears, beginning on April
15, 2003, at a rate of 5.625%.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">In 2001, we issued the following unsecured
notes under a $2.5&nbsp;billion shelf
registration statement filed with the
Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC)&nbsp;in
October 2000:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">In October, we issued $600&nbsp;million senior
unsecured notes, which pay interest
semi-annually, beginning on May&nbsp;1, 2002, at
a rate of 3.625%.</FONT></TD>
</TR>

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements<BR>
PFIZER INC AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">In February 2003, we issued:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">$300&nbsp;million senior unsecured notes, due
March 2009, which pay interest
semi-annually, beginning on September&nbsp;2,
2003, at a rate of 3.3%; and</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">$300&nbsp;million senior unsecured notes, due
March 2018, which pay interest
semi-annually, beginning on September&nbsp;1,
2003, at a rate of 4.65%.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The notes were issued under a $5&nbsp;billion
debt shelf registration statement filed
with the SEC in November 2002.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">In connection with these debt issuances, we entered into:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">$300&nbsp;million notional amount of interest
rate swaps maturing in 2009; and</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">$300&nbsp;million notional amount of interest rate swaps maturing in 2018.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We designated these interest rate swaps as
fair value hedges of the changes in the
fair value of fixed rate debt. These swaps
serve to reduce our exposure to long-term
U.S. interest rates by effectively
converting the fixed rates associated with
the long-term debt to floating rates.</font>


<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We have approximately $6.9&nbsp;billion in
available borrowings between unused lines
of credit and debt securities under a shelf
registration statement filed with the SEC.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>D.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Derivative Financial Instruments and Hedging Activities</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">PURPOSE
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Foreign Exchange Risk</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">A significant portion of revenues, earnings
and net investments in foreign affiliates
are exposed to changes in foreign exchange
rates. We seek to manage our foreign
exchange risk in part through operational
means, including managing expected local
currency revenues in relation to local
currency costs and local currency assets in
relation to local currency liabilities.
Foreign exchange risk is also managed
through the use of derivative financial
instruments and foreign currency
denominated debt. These financial
instruments serve to protect net income
against the impact of the translation into
U.S. dollars of certain foreign exchange
denominated transactions. At December&nbsp;31,
2002 and 2001, the financial instruments
employed to manage foreign exchange risk
follow:
</FONT>
<CENTER>
<TABLE cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="90%">
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="21%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="11%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="37%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="10%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="3"><FONT size="1"><B>NOTIONAL AMOUNT</B></FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Interest Rate Risk</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Our interest-bearing investments, loans and borrowings are subject to interest rate risk. We invest and borrow primarily on a short-term or variable-rate basis. Interest rate risk is also managed through the use of derivative financial instruments. At
December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001, the derivative financial instruments employed to manage interest rate risk follow:
</FONT>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2"><SUP>(1)</SUP></FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Serve to reduce variability by effectively fixing the maximum rates on
short-term debt at 1.2%.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2"><SUP>(2)</SUP></FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Serve to reduce variability by effectively fixing the maximum rates on
short-term debt at .9%. These forward-starting swaps will effectively replace
existing yen interest rate swaps upon maturity in 2003.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2"><SUP>(3)</SUP></FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Serve to reduce exposure to long-term U.S. dollar interest rates by
effectively converting fixed rates associated with long-term debt obligations
to floating rates.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2"><SUP>(4)</SUP></FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Serve to reduce the variability of LIBOR interest rates by effectively
fixing the rates on short-term debt securities at 3.5%. Investments will be
classified as &#147;Available-for-Sale.&#148;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="right"><FONT size="2">ANNUAL REPORT 2002</FONT>


<P align="center"><FONT size="2">P 53</FONT>




<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements<BR>
PFIZER INC AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</b>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">ACCOUNTING POLICIES
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">All derivative contracts are reported at fair value, with changes in fair value
reported in earnings or deferred, depending on the nature and effectiveness
of the offset or hedging relationship, as follows:
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Foreign Exchange Risk
</FONT>

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">We recognize the earnings impact of foreign currency forward-exchange
contracts during the terms of the contracts, along with the earnings
impact of the items they generally offset.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">We recognize the earnings impact of foreign currency swaps designated
as cash flow or fair value hedges upon the recognition of the foreign
exchange gain or loss on the translation to U.S. dollars of the hedged
item.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">We recognize the earnings impact of yen put options when the related
inventory is sold to third-party customers.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Interest Rate Risk
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">We recognize the earnings impact of interest rate swaps designated as
cash flow hedges upon the recognition of the interest related to the hedged
short-term debt and available-for-sale debt securities.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">We recognize the earnings impact of interest rate swaps designated as
fair value hedges upon the recognition of the change in fair value for interest
rate risk related to the hedged long-term debt.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Any ineffectiveness in a hedging relationship is recognized immediately into
earnings. There was no significant ineffectiveness in 2002 or 2001.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The financial statements include the following items related to the
derivatives and other financial instruments serving as offsets or hedges:
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Prepaid expenses and taxes</I> includes:
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;fair value of foreign currency put options
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Other assets, deferred taxes and deferred charges</I> includes:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">fair value of forward-starting interest rate swaps in 2002 and
interest rate swaps</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Other current liabilities</I> includes:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

fair value of foreign currency swaps designated as cash flow
hedges<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;in 2001
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>E.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Fair Value</B></FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The following methods and assumptions were used to estimate the fair value
of derivative and other financial instruments at the balance sheet date:
</FONT>

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">short-term financial instruments (cash equivalents, accounts
receivable and payable, held-to-maturity short-term investments and debt)-we use
cost or contract value because of the short maturity period</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Available-for-sale debt securities
&#151; we use a valuation model that
uses observable market quotes and credit ratings of the securities</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Derivative contracts &#151; we use valuation models that use observable
market quotes and our view of the creditworthiness of the derivative
counterparty</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">loans-we use cost because of the short interest-reset period</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">held-to-maturity long-term investments and long-term debt &#151; we use
valuation models that use observable market quotes</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The differences between the estimated fair values and carrying values of our
financial instruments were not material at December&nbsp;31, 2002.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>F.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Credit Risk</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We periodically review the creditworthiness of counterparties to foreign
exchange and interest rate agreements and do not expect to incur a loss from
failure of any counterparties to perform under the agreements. In general,
there is no requirement for collateral from customers. There are no significant
concentrations of credit risk related to our financial instruments with any
individual counterparty. At December&nbsp;31, 2002, we had $2,885&nbsp;million due from a broad
group of banks around the world.
</FONT>

<P>
<CENTER>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">*</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">As a result of adopting SFAS No.&nbsp;142, we recorded a write-down of $536&nbsp;million for the
impairment provisions related to goodwill in our animal health business. The fair value of
the animal health business was determined using discounted cash flows. The write-down is
reported as a cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle as of the beginning of
2002.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</CENTER>

in 2002 and $54&nbsp;million in 2001. Amortization expense for finite-lived
intangible assets is recorded in various expenses, including <I>Cost of sales,
Research and development expenses and Other (income)/ deductions-net.</I></FONT>

</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Amounts are reflected in the preceding tables based on the location of the
taxing authorities. As of December&nbsp;31, 2002, we have not made a U.S. tax
provision on approximately $29&nbsp;billion of unremitted earnings of our
international subsidiaries. These earnings are expected, for the most part, to
be reinvested overseas. It is not practical to compute the estimated deferred
tax liability on these earnings.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We operate manufacturing subsidiaries in Puerto Rico that benefit from
Puerto Rican incentive grants that expire at the end of 2015. Under the
grants, we are partially exempt from income, property and municipal taxes.
Under Section&nbsp;936 of the U.S. Internal Revenue Code, Pfizer is a
&#147;grandfathered&#148; entity and is entitled to the benefits under such statute until
2006.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">ANNUAL REPORT 2002</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">P56</FONT>

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

</TABLE>
</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Deferred taxes arise because of different
treatment between financial statement
accounting and tax accounting, known as
&#147;temporary differences.&#148; We record the tax
effect of these temporary differences as
&#147;deferred tax assets&#148; (generally items that
can be used as a tax deduction or credit in
future periods) or &#147;deferred tax
liabilities&#148; (generally items for which we
received a tax deduction but that have not
yet been recorded in the consolidated
statement of income).
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The tax effects of the major items recorded
as deferred tax assets and liabilities are:
</FONT>
<CENTER>
<TABLE cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="65%">

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><HR size="4" noshade></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">A valuation allowance is recorded because some items recorded as deferred
tax assets may ultimately not be deductible or creditable. The foreign tax
credit carryforwards were generated from dividends paid or deemed to be
paid by subsidiaries to the parent company between 1998 and 2001. We can
carry these credits forward for five years from the year of actual payment
and apply them to certain U.S. tax liabilities.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Deferred tax assets and liabilities in the preceding table, netted by taxing
location, are in the following captions in the consolidated balance sheet:

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The Internal Revenue Service (IRS)&nbsp;has completed and closed its audits of
our tax returns through 1998 and Warner-Lambert Company through 1995.
The IRS is currently conducting audits of Pfizer Inc&#146;s tax returns for the
years 1999 and 2000 and Warner-Lambert Company for the years 1996
through 1998.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">In November 1994, Belgian tax authorities notified Pfizer Research and
Development Company N.V./S.A. (PRDCO), an indirect, wholly owned
subsidiary of our company, of a proposed adjustment to the taxable income
of PRDCO for fiscal year 1992 and, in January 1996, PRDCO received an
assessment from the tax authorities for fiscal year 1993. On May&nbsp;14, 2002,
PRDCO reached an agreement with the Belgian authorities to settle this
matter for an immaterial amount.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We believe that our accruals for tax liabilities are adequate for all open
years.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>12.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;BENEFIT PLANS</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We provide defined benefit pension plans
and defined contribution plans for the
majority of employees worldwide. In the
U.S., we have both qualified and
supplemental (non-qualified) defined
benefit plans. A qualified plan meets the
requirements of certain sections of the
Internal Revenue Code and enjoys special
tax advantages. It typically provides
benefits to a broad group of employees and
may not discriminate in favor of highly
compensated employees in its coverage,
benefits or contributions. We also provide
benefits through supplemental
(non-qualified) retirement plans to certain
employees. These supplemental plans, which
are not generally funded, provide out of
our general assets an amount substantially
equal to the difference between the amounts
that would have been payable under the
qualified defined benefit pension plans, in
the absence of legislation limiting pension
benefits and earnings that may be
considered in calculating pension benefits,
and the amounts actually payable under the
qualified defined benefit pension plans. In
addition, we provide medical and life
insurance benefits to retirees and their
eligible dependents through our
postretirement plans.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">It is our practice to fund amounts for our
qualified pension plans at least sufficient
to meet the minimum requirements set forth
in applicable employee benefit laws and
local tax laws. Liabilities for amounts in
excess of these funding levels are included
in our consolidated balance sheet. Our U.S.
qualified pension plans have been
well-funded historically and the recent
decline in the equity markets coupled with
the decline in long-term interest rates has
not caused our pension plans to require
government-mandated funding. In 2002, we
made voluntary contributions in excess of
minimum requirements of $485&nbsp;million to our
U.S. qualified plans and $125&nbsp;million to
our U.K. pension plans.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Our plan assets comprise a diversified mix
of investments consisting principally of
stocks and fixed income securities. At
December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001, stocks
represented 74% and 77% of the market value
of
</FONT>
<P align="right"><FONT size="2">ANNUAL REPORT 2002</FONT>


<P align="center"><FONT size="2">P57</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements<BR>
PFIZER INC AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</b>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">pension assets in our U.S. qualified
defined benefit pension plans. Certain
international subsidiaries have plans where
accruals are provided or annuities are
purchased under group contracts.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The major U.S. pension plans held
approximately 8.7&nbsp;million shares (fair
value of approximately $265&nbsp;million) at
December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 7.7&nbsp;million shares
(fair value of approximately $307&nbsp;million)
at December&nbsp;31, 2001 of our common stock.
The plans received approximately $4&nbsp;million
in dividends on these shares in 2002 and
approximately $3&nbsp;million in dividends in
2001.
</FONT>

</CENTER>
<P>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">*</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Reduced to 9% for 2003.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The net periodic benefit cost and the actuarial present value of projected
benefit obligations are based on actuarial assumptions that are reviewed on
an annual basis. We revise these assumptions based on an annual evaluation
of long-term trends, as well as market conditions, that may have an impact on
the cost of providing retirement benefits and in accordance with the
requirements of SFAS No.&nbsp;87, <i>Employers&#146; Accounting for
Pensions.</i>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The annual cost of the U.S. and international pension plans follow:

<TR valign="top">

    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Includes special termination benefits of $38&nbsp;million in 2000.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">U.S. plans include supplemental (non-qualified) retirement plans with benefit costs of

    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">U.S. supplemental (non-qualified) retirement plans have no assets, as the obligation is paid

    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">***</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">U.S. plans include supplemental (non-qualified) retirement plans with plan assets in 2002
and 2001 less than PBO of ($804) million in 2002 and ($684) million in 2001.</FONT></TD>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">ANNUAL REPORT 2002
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">P58</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>



<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements<BR>
PFIZER INC AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The increase in the underfunded status of the pension plans in 2002 and
2001 results primarily from a continuing decrease in the discount rate used
in calculating plan liabilities coupled with the effect on plan assets of the
decline in global equity markets. The increase in unrecognized actuarial loss
is largely reflective of this decline in global equity markets since the
difference between the expected return and actual return in plan assets is
largely deferred. A portion of the increase is also the result of using a lower
discount rate to calculate the present value of our liabilities. In response to
these developments, in 2002 we made voluntary contributions in excess of
minimum requirements of $485&nbsp;million to our U.S. qualified defined benefit
pension plans and $125&nbsp;million to our U.K. pension plans. In 2001, we made
a voluntary contribution in excess of minimum requirements of $385&nbsp;million
to our U.S. qualified defined benefit pension plans.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The components of the net pension asset/(liability) recorded in the
consolidated balance sheet consist of:
</FONT>
<CENTER>
<TABLE cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="75%">
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="48%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="4%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="4%">&nbsp;</TD>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">*</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">U.S. plans represent supplemental (non-qualified) retirement plans with an ABO of
$599&nbsp;million in 2002 and $541&nbsp;million in 2001.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">**</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">U.S. plans include supplemental (non-qualified) retirement plans with a PBO of
$804&nbsp;million in 2002 and $684&nbsp;million in 2001.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Plans with an ABO in excess of plan assets are primarily our U.S.
supplemental retirement plans which are not funded, as well as our plans in
the U.K, Japan and Germany, whose liabilities are included in our
consolidated balance sheet. Our U.S. qualified defined benefit pension plans
which provide benefits to substantially all of our U.S. employees, had assets
greater than their ABO at December&nbsp;31, 2002.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Plans with PBOs in excess of plan assets are primarily our U.S. qualified
defined benefit pension plans; U.S. supplemental (non-qualified) retirement
plans, which are not generally funded; and our plans in the U.K., Japan and
Germany, whose liabilities are included in our consolidated balance sheet.
</FONT>

</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">An average increase of 9% in the cost of health care benefits was assumed
for 2003 and is projected to decrease over the next six years to 5% and then
remain at that level.
</FONT>
<P align="right"><FONT size="2">ANNUAL REPORT 2002</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">P59</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>



<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements<BR>
PFIZER INC AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B>
</FONT>

</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We have savings and investment plans in several countries including the
U.S. and Puerto Rico. Employees may contribute a portion of their salaries
to the plans, and we match, in company stock, a portion of the employee
contributions. The contribution and match for U.S. participants are held in
an employee stock ownership plan (ESOP)&nbsp;that was adopted in 2002. The
value of our stock contributions were $139&nbsp;million in 2002, $107&nbsp;million in
2001 and $86&nbsp;million in 2000.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>13.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;LEASE COMMITMENTS</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We lease properties and equipment for use in our operations. In addition to
rent, the leases may require us to pay directly for taxes, insurance,
maintenance and other operating expenses, or to pay higher rent when
operating expenses increase. Rental expense, net of sublease income, was
$341&nbsp;million in 2002, $280&nbsp;million in 2001 and $292&nbsp;million in 2000. This
table shows future minimum rental commitments under noncancellable
operating leases at December&nbsp;31, 2002:

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>14.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;COMMON STOCK</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">In December 2002, our shareholders approved the issuance of up to 1.804
billion shares of our common stock to Pharmacia shareholders in connection
with the proposed acquisition of Pharmacia. Also in 2002, we announced a
new $16&nbsp;billion share-purchase program (increased from the initial $10
billion) authorized by our board of directors. We will buy back our common
stock via open market purchases or in privately negotiated transactions as
circumstances and prices warrant, with the anticipation of completing the
share-purchase program in 2003. Under this current share-purchase
program, we purchased approximately 102&nbsp;million shares of common stock
at an average price of $29.41 per share, at a total cost of approximately
$3&nbsp;billion, in 2002. In May 2002, we completed the share-purchase program
authorized in June 2001. In total, under the June 2001 program we purchased
120&nbsp;million shares at a total cost of approximately $4.8&nbsp;billion. In 2002,
under both the 2002 and 2001 programs, we purchased approximately 153&nbsp;million
shares of common stock at a total cost of approximately $5&nbsp;billion.
Purchased shares are available for general corporate purposes.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">In 2001, we purchased approximately 68.5&nbsp;million shares of our common
stock in the open market at an average price of $40.83 per share under the
June 2001 share-purchase program and approximately 20.3&nbsp;million shares of
our common stock at an average price of $42.72 per share under the
September 1998 share-purchase program. In 2000,we purchased approximately 23.1&nbsp;million shares of our common stock in the open market
at an average price of $43.46 per share.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>15.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;PREFERRED STOCK PURCHASE RIGHTS</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Preferred Stock Purchase Rights have a scheduled term through October
2007, although the term may be extended or the rights may be redeemed
prior to expiration. One right was issued for each share of common stock
issued by our company. These rights are not exercisable unless certain
change-in-control events transpire, such as a person acquiring or obtaining
the right to acquire beneficial ownership of 15% or more of our outstanding
common stock or an announcement of a tender offer for at least 30% of our
stock. The rights are evidenced by corresponding common stock certificates
and automatically trade with the common stock unless an event transpires
that makes them exercisable. If the rights become exercisable, separate
certificates evidencing the rights will be distributed and each right will
entitle the holder to purchase a new series of preferred stock at a defined
price from our company. The preferred stock, in addition to preferred
dividend and liquidation rights, will entitle the holder to vote with the
company&#146;s common stock.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The rights are redeemable by us at a fixed price until 10&nbsp;days, or longer as
determined by the board of directors, after certain defined events, or at any
time prior to the expiration of the rights.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We have reserved 3.0&nbsp;million preferred shares to be issued pursuant to these
rights. No such shares have yet been issued. At the present time, the rights
have no dilutive effect on the earnings per common share calculation.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>16.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;EMPLOYEE BENEFIT TRUST</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The Pfizer Inc. Employee Benefit Trust (EBT)&nbsp;was established in 1999 to
fund our employee benefit plans through the use of its holding of Pfizer Inc.
stock. The consolidated balance sheet reflects the fair value of the shares
owned by the EBT as a reduction of <I>Shareholders&#146; equity</I>.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Stock options and stock issuable under employee compensation plans
representing equivalents of 244&nbsp;million shares of common stock during 2002
and 136&nbsp;million shares of common stock during 2001 had exercise prices
greater than the average market price of Pfizer common stock. These
common stock equivalents were outstanding during 2002 and 2001, but
were not included in the computation of diluted earnings per share for those
years because their inclusion would have had an anti-dilutive effect. There
were no anti-dilutive common stock equivalents during 2000.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">ANNUAL REPORT 2002
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">P60</FONT>

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>



<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements</B><BR>
<B>PFIZER INC AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>18.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;STOCK OPTION AND PERFORMANCE UNIT AWARDS</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We have stock and incentive plans related to employees that allow for stock
options, performance unit awards and stock awards.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We may grant stock options to employees, including officers, under the
plans. Options are exercisable after five years or less, subject to continuous
employment and certain other conditions, and expire 10&nbsp;years after the grant
date. Once exercisable, the employee can purchase shares of our common
stock at the market price on the date we granted the option. The 1996 Stock
Plan, a former Warner-Lambert plan, provided that, in the event of a change
in control of Warner-Lambert, stock options already granted became
exercisable immediately.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The following shares were available for award (in thousands) at:
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;December&nbsp;31,
2000 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;137,248
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;December&nbsp;31, 2001 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;249,572
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;December&nbsp;31, 2002 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;178,626
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The table below summarizes information concerning options outstanding
under the plans at December&nbsp;31, 2002:
</FONT>

for 2002, $15.12 for 2001 and $11.12 for 2000. We estimated the fair values
using the Black-Scholes option pricing model, modified for dividends and
using the following assumptions:

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>




</TABLE>
</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">In 2001, our shareholders approved a new Performance-Contingent Share
Award Plan (the Plan) allowing a maximum of 12.5&nbsp;million shares to be
awarded. The Plan replaces the Performance-Contingent Share Award
Program (the Program) that was established and became effective in 1993
to provide executives and other key employees the right to earn common
stock awards. Similar to the previous Program, determination of award
payouts under the Plan is made after the performance period ends, based
upon specific performance criteria. Under the previous Program, up to
120&nbsp;million shares could be awarded. The actual number of shares awarded
and pending under the previous Program since its approval is 21&nbsp;million
shares. At December&nbsp;31, 2002, participants had the right to earn up to 8.0
million shares under the previous Program and up to 2.8&nbsp;million additional
shares under the new Plan. Awards for performance periods beginning prior
to January&nbsp;1, 2002 will be made under the previous Program. Awards for
performance periods beginning January&nbsp;1, 2002 will be made under the new
Plan. Under the previous Program, we awarded approximately 2.0&nbsp;million
shares in 2002, approximately 1.7&nbsp;million shares in 2001 and approximately
2.3&nbsp;million shares in 2000. We did not award any shares under the new Plan
as of December&nbsp;31, 2002. Compensation expense related to the previous
Program and to the new Plan was $36&nbsp;million in 2002, $94&nbsp;million in 2001
and $170&nbsp;million in 2000.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We entered into forward-purchase contracts that offset the potential impact
on net income of our liability under the Program. At settlement date we will,
at the option of the counterparty to each of the contracts, either receive our
own stock or settle the contracts for cash. Other contract terms are as
follows:
</FONT>
<CENTER>

<P align="right"><FONT size="2">ANNUAL REPORT 2002</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">P61</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>



<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements</B><BR>
<B>PFIZER INC AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>19.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;INSURANCE</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Our insurance coverage reflects market conditions (including cost and
availability) existing at the time it is written, and the relationship of
insurance coverage to self-insurance varies accordingly. As a result of recent external
events, the cost of insurance has risen substantially and the availability of
insurance has become more restrictive. Thus, depending upon the cost of
insurance and the nature of the risk involved, the amount of self-insurance
may be significant. We consider the impact of these changes as we continually
assess the best way to provide for our insurance needs in the future.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>20.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;LEGAL PROCEEDINGS AND CONTINGENCIES</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We and certain of our subsidiaries are involved in various patent, product
liability, consumer, commercial, environmental, and tax litigations and claims;
government investigations; and other legal proceedings that arise from time to
time in the ordinary course of our business. We do not believe any of them will
have a material adverse effect on our financial position. Litigation is
inherently unpredictable, and excessive verdicts do occur. Although we believe we have
valid defenses in these matters, we could in the future incur judgments or
enter into settlements of claims that could have a material adverse effect on our
results of operations in any particular period.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Patent claims include challenges to the coverage and/or validity of our patents
on various products or processes. Although we believe that we have valid
defenses to these challenges with respect to all our material patents, there
can be no assurance as to the outcome of these matters, and a loss in any of these
cases could result in a loss of patent protection for the drug at issue, which
could lead to a significant loss of sales of that drug and could materially
affect future results of operations.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Among the principal matters pending to which we are a party are the following:
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">PATENT MATTERS
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We are involved in a number of patent suits, the majority of which involve
claims by generic drug manufacturers that patents covering our products,
processes or dosage forms are invalid and/or do not cover the product of the
generic manufacturer. Pending suits include generic challenges to patents
covering, among other products, amlodipine <I>(Norvasc)</I>, gabapentin <I>(Neurontin)</I>,
fluconazole <I>(Diflucan)</I>, nifedipine <I>(Procardia XL)</I> and quinapril <I>(Accupril)</I>. In
addition, counterclaims in these suits as well as various independent actions
(in connection with gabapentin and nifedipine) have been filed claiming that
our assertions of or attempts to enforce our patent rights constitute unfair
competition and/or violations of the antitrust laws. With respect to <I>Zoloft</I> and
<I>Lipitor</I>, generic companies are challenging certain of our patents; however, due
to the existence of additional patents, the outcome of these challenges will
not affect the timing of generic competition with these products.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Norvasc (amlodipine)</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">A manufacturer has filed an application with the FDA seeking approval to market
amlodipine maleate, a different salt form from amlodipine besylate, which
is employed in our product, <I>Norvasc</I>. The basic patent for <I>Norvasc</I> received an
extension of term under the Hatch-Waxman Act. The manufacturer asserts that
during the period of extension the exclusionary rights of the patent are
restricted to amlodipine besylate and that, after the original February 2003 expiration
date, sales of amlodipine maleate would not infringe our patent. In June 2002,
we filed a patent infringement suit against the manufacturer in the U.S.
District Court for the District of New Jersey. The manufacturer&#146;s motion to dismiss the
complaint was granted in December 2002, and we have appealed that decision.
If our appeal is not successful and the manufacturer&#146;s product is approved and
marketed, our sales of <I>Norvasc</I> could be subject to competition from the
amlodipine maleate product. We believe that our pediatric exclusivity would
preclude the manufacturer from marketing an amlodipine maleate product until
August 2003 even if its position regarding the scope of the patent during the
extension period is upheld in litigation. A different manufacturer has filed an
abbreviated new drug application with the FDA seeking to market a generic
version of amlodipine besylate, asserting the invalidity of our amlodipine
patents. We also filed a patent infringement suit against that manufacturer in
the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey in October 2002.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Neurontin (gabapentin)</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">In 2000, Warner-Lambert brought patent infringement suits in various federal
courts against several generic manufacturers that have filed abbreviated new
drug applications with the FDA asserting the invalidity and non-infringement
of our gabapentin <I>(Neurontin)</I> low-lactam patent. These suits have been consolidated for pre-trial purposes in the U.S. District Court for the District of
New Jersey. The defendants have filed various summary judgment motions asserting
invalidity and non-infringement on a number of grounds, and responses
have been filed. The 30-month stay of FDA approval triggered by the lawsuits
has expired with respect to some of these generic manufacturers and will expire
as to the others in 2003; and each of these generic manufacturers has received
an approvable letter from the FDA. Counterclaims in these suits as well as
various independent actions have been filed claiming that our assertions of or
attempts to enforce rights under our patents for gabapentin constitute unfair
competition and/or violations of the antitrust laws. These counterclaims and
independent actions have been consolidated in the same federal court and
stayed pending the outcome of the patent infringement suits. In addition, on
February&nbsp;5, 2003, Warner-Lambert brought a patent infringement suit in the
U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania against another
generic manufacturer alleging infringement of our gabapentin <I>(Neurontin)</I> low-
lactam patent and another patent.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Diflucan (fluconazole)</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Our suit against a generic manufacturer alleging infringement of our patent on
fluconazole <I>(Diflucan)</I>, filed in the U.S. District Court for the Northern
District of Illinois in 2000, resulted in our obtaining a summary judgment of
infringement. After entry of a consent judgment, the case was settled without
adverse effect to the Company. Following the decision in Illinois, we brought suit
against another generic manufacturer in May 2002 in the U.S. District Court
for the District of New Jersey alleging that such manufacturer&#146;s intention to
produce fluconazole <I>(Diflucan)</I> would infringe the same Pfizer patent that was
involved in the Illinois case.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">ANNUAL REPORT 2002
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">P62</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements</B><BR>
<B>PFIZER INC AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Celebrex, Bextra (celecoxib, valdecoxib)</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">In 2000, the University of Rochester filed a patent infringement action against
Pfizer, G.D. Searle &#038; Co., Inc., Monsanto Co., and Pharmacia Corporation, in
the U.S. District Court for the Western District of New York, alleging that
sales of <I>Celebrex</I> infringe the broad method of use claims of the University&#146;s patent.
The suit also alleges infringement by <I>Bextra.</I> Summary judgment motions were
filed by both sides in 2002 and are awaiting decision.
</FONT>







<P align="left"><FONT size="2">PRODUCT LIABILITY MATTERS
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Rezulin</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The <I>Rezulin</I> litigation arises from a diabetes drug developed by Sankyo in
Japan and by Warner-Lambert. <I>Rezulin</I> was reported to have been prescribed
to approximately two million patients. The medication treated insulin
resistance, which is the cause of type 2 diabetes, and was effective for many
patients whose diabetes had not been controlled with other medications. We believe
that the FDA-approved labeling and warnings appropriately communicated the
risks associated with the medication, including the risk of liver injury, which
occurred in a small percentage of patients. <I>Rezulin</I> was voluntarily withdrawn
by Warner-Lambert in March 2000 following approval of two newer diabetes
medications, which the FDA considered to have similar efficacy and fewer side
effects.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">As of December&nbsp;31, 2002, suits involving approximately 8,700 alleged users
of <I>Rezulin</I> had been filed in various federal and state courts. Many of these
suits are at a preliminary stage. In the vast majority of these cases, we have
not yet obtained and reviewed complete information regarding the plaintiffs and
their medical conditions, and consequently, we are unable to fully evaluate the
claims. A number of cases have been settled, and a smaller number have been
tried, producing verdicts both for and against Warner-Lambert. We have
appealed and will continue to appeal verdicts rendered in favor of plaintiffs
that we believe are inappropriate and that have not otherwise been resolved.
The cases pending in federal courts have all been consolidated for pre-trial
proceedings in a single multi-district litigation assigned to the U.S. District
Court for the Southern District of NewYork. On September&nbsp;12, 2002, the court
denied the plaintiffs&#146; motion to certify a class of allegedly injured <I>Rezulin</I>
users seeking money damages and a subclass of uninjured users seeking medical
monitoring and damages for alleged consumer fraud or restitution of amounts
they paid for <I>Rezulin.</I> A number of the cases pending in state courts are
purported class actions.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">In addition, as of December&nbsp;31, 2002, approximately 1,000 alleged users of
<I>Rezulin</I> had asserted claims, but had not filed suits, against the Company.
Also, as of December&nbsp;31, 2002, we had agreed with certain plaintiffs&#146; lawyers to
extend the statute of limitations for approximately 31,000 individuals who do
not have lawsuits on file and who may or may not eventually pursue claims.
We are unable to determine how many, if any, of these individuals may be able
to assert claims for <I>Rezulin</I>-related injury.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We are actively engaged in defending these various lawsuits and, where
appropriate, resolving the suits and claims. As in most mass tort litigation,
the cases present a wide variety of claims, ranging from allegations of serious
injury caused by <I>Rezulin</I> to efforts to obtain compensation notwithstanding the
absence of any injury at all. Based on the information available to us at this
time, only a small percentage of the claimants have suffered any serious or
permanent injury caused by the medication. We are not aware of any reliable
evidence supporting a conclusion that <I>Rezulin</I> had any adverse latent effect.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">One of our insurance carriers that provides the first layer of excess coverage
for these <I>Rezulin</I> claims has denied coverage. We believe that the carrier&#146;s
position is without merit. If we are unable to resolve the matter satisfactorily with
the carrier, we intend to initiate an arbitration proceeding to resolve the dispute
and we would expect to prevail.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">A federal grand jury in Maryland has sought documents relating to <I>Rezulin</I>
from us and testimony from former Warner-Lambert employees. We are
cooperating fully with this investigation.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Asbestos</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">In the 1960s, Pfizer acquired two businesses, the Gibsonburg Lime Products
Company and Quigley Company, Inc., that sold, among other things, products
containing small amounts of asbestos. The sale of these products was
discontinued in the early 1970s. Gibsonburg Lime was operated as an
unincorporated division of Pfizer, whereas Quigley has been and continues to be a separately
incorporated subsidiary of Pfizer. As of December&nbsp;31, 2002, approximately
128,000 claims naming Pfizer and/or Quigley and numerous other defendants
were pending in various federal and state courts seeking damages for alleged
asbestos exposure. The majority of these claims involve alleged activities of
Quigley, for which any liability is solely the responsibility of Quigley. While
Quigley continues to have insurance covering asbestos claims, that insurance
is limited and going forward contains substantial self-insurance aspects.
Quigley has conducted no active trade or business since 1992. Its sole activity
is management of its asbestos-related claims.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Between 1967 and 1982, Warner-Lambert owned American Optical
Corporation, which manufactured and sold respiratory protective devices and
asbestos safety clothing. In connection with the sale of American Optical in
1982, Warner-Lambert agreed to indemnify the purchaser for certain liabilities,
including certain asbestos-related and other claims. As of December&nbsp;31, 2002,
approximately 103,000 claims naming American Optical and numerous other
defendants were pending in various federal and state courts seeking damages
for alleged asbestos and other exposures. Several of the insurance carriers
that provided coverage for the American Optical asbestos and other claims have
denied coverage. We believe that these carriers&#146; position is without merit and
have initiated legal proceedings against such carriers.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Based upon available data and our experience in handling asbestos claims, we
believe that a substantial portion of the plaintiffs alleging injury from
Pfizer, Quigley and American Optical products do not have any impairing medical
condition. For those claimants who do, we believe we have meritorious
defenses.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>OTHER MATTERS</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Environmental Matters</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We are a party to a number of proceedings brought under the Comprehensive
Environmental Response Compensation and Liability Act of 1980 (CERCLA
or Superfund) and comparable state laws in which the primary relief sought is
the cost of past and future remediation.
</FONT>
<P align="right"><FONT size="2">ANNUAL REPORT 2002</FONT>


<P align="center"><FONT size="2">P63</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>



<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements</B><BR>
<B>PFIZER INC AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Neurontin</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The U.S. Attorney&#146;s office in Boston, Massachusetts has been conducting an
investigation into Warner-Lambert&#146;s promotion of <i>Neurontin</i>. The investigation
originated with a <i>qui tam</i> lawsuit filed in the U.S. District Court for the
District of Massachusetts by a former Warner-Lambert employee, alleging that
Warner-Lambert violated the Federal False Claims Act based on certain sales
and marketing practices concerning <i>Neurontin</i>. These allegations are also under
review by a group of state attorneys general. We continue to cooperate fully
with these inquiries. While it is possible that criminal charges and fines
and/or civil penalties could result from these investigations, we are unable to
estimate the amount of any such fines or penalties. These allegations also are the
subject of a suit filed by certain individuals in the U.S. District Court for the
Northern District of West Virginia in June 2002 and a suit filed by the Congress
of California Seniors, et al., in the Superior Court of California for Los Angeles County in February 2003.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Zithromax</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The previously reported investigation by a coalition of nineteen state
attorneys general into the promotion of <i>Zithromax</i> for otitis media has been concluded
by our entering into an assurance of voluntary compliance that included the
payment of $6&nbsp;million to cover investigation costs and to fund certain public
service announcements.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><b>Average Wholesale Price
Litigation</b></font>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">On September&nbsp;10, 2002, we were named as a defendant in a purported consolidated class action that previously had been pending in a multi-district
proceeding in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts. The
amended complaint alleges that Pfizer and other pharmaceutical manufacturers
defrauded the plaintiff health care insurers and payors by selling certain
products at prices lower than the published average wholesale price at which
the products were reimbursed by the plaintiffs. We also were named as a
defendant in suits involving substantially similar allegations in the Superior
Court of California for Los Angeles County on September&nbsp;26, 2002, and in the U.S.
District Court for the Eastern District of New York on January&nbsp;17, 2003.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">MERGER LITIGATION
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Warner-Lambert Acquisition</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The previously reported shareholder class and derivative suits filed in New
Jersey and Delaware in respect of Pfizer&#146;s acquisition of Warner-Lambert,
which generally alleged that Warner-Lambert directors breached their fiduciary
obligations to Warner-Lambert shareholders in connection with the initial
agreement to merge with American Home Products and then with Pfizer, have
all been resolved and dismissed.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Pharmacia Acquisition</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Following the announcement on July&nbsp;15, 2002 of our agreement to acquire
Pharmacia Corporation, a suit was filed in the Delaware Chancery Court on
behalf of a purported class of Pharmacia&#146;s shareholders against Pharmacia and
its directors and Pfizer. The suit alleges that the price to be paid for
Pharmacia&#146;s shares was inadequate as a result of the breach by Pharmacia&#146;s directors of
their fiduciary duties to the Pharmacia shareholders and that Pfizer aided and
abetted the alleged breach. The complaint, which we believe to be without
merit, seeks damages and injunctive relief.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">ANNUAL REPORT 2002
</FONT>


<P align="center"><FONT size="2">P64</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>21. SEGMENT, GEOGRAPHIC AND REVENUE INFORMATION</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We operate in the following two business segments:</FONT>

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">pharmaceutical &#151; including:</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="4%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#150;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="92%"><FONT size="2">treatments for cardiovascular diseases, infectious diseases, central
nervous system disorders, diabetes, arthritis, urogenital conditions and
allergies, as well as the manufacture of empty soft-gelatin capsules</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="4%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#150;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="92%"><FONT size="2">products for livestock and companion animals</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">consumer products &#151; including self-medications for:</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="4%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#150;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="92%"><FONT size="2">oral care, upper respiratory health, eye care, skin care and gastro-intestinal health</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Each separately managed segment offers different products requiring different
marketing and distribution strategies.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We sell our products primarily to customers in the wholesale sector. In 2002,
sales to our three largest wholesalers represented 45% of total revenues.
These sales were concentrated in the pharmaceutical segment.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Revenues exceeded $500&nbsp;million in each of seven countries outside the U.S. in
2002. The U.S. was the only country to contribute more than 10% of total
revenues. The following tables present segment, geographic and revenue
information:
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>SEGMENT</B>
</FONT>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">(1)</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Includes an increase to revenues of $175&nbsp;million from the
harmonization of Pfizer/Warner-Lambert accounting methodology for Medicaid
discounts and contract rebate accruals.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">(2)</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Reflects reclassification of certain marketing expenses as a result
of adopting EITF Issue No.&nbsp;00-25 and certain sales incentives as a result of
adopting EITF Issue No.&nbsp;00-14. Both reclassifications were from <I>Selling,
informational and administrative expenses to Revenues</I>.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">(3)</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Includes costs of $136&nbsp;million associated with the withdrawal of
Rezulin, a loss on the sale of animal health&#146;s feed-additive products of $85
million and a gain on the sale of Omnicef of $39&nbsp;million.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">(4)</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Includes a gain on the sale of the Rid line of lice-control
products of $78&nbsp;million.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">(5)</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Includes interest income/(expense) and corporate expenses.
Corporate/Other also includes other income/(expense) of our banking and
insurance subsidiaries (see note 5, &#147;Banking and Insurance Subsidiaries&#148;),
certain performance-based compensation expenses not allocated to the
operating segments and merger-related costs.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">(6)</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Equals income from continuing operations before provision for taxes
on income, minority interests and cumulative effect of a change in accounting
principle.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">(7)</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Certain production facilities are shared by various segments.
Property, plant and equipment, as well as capital additions and depreciation,
are allocated based on physical production. Corporate assets are primarily
cash, short-term investments, long-term loans and investments and assets held
for sale of the Adams and Schick-Wilkinson Sword businesses (and the Tetra
business in 2001 and 2000) and women&#146;s health product lines.</FONT></TD>
</TR>

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>



<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>Quarterly Consolidated Financial Data (Unaudited)</B><BR>
<B>PFIZER INC AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B>
</FONT>

</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">All financial information reflects our confectionery, shaving and fish-care
products businesses, as well as the femhrt, Loestrin and Estrostep women&#146;s
health product lines, as discontinued operations.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Merger-related costs </I>include transaction, integration and restructuring costs
related to our merger with Warner-Lambert. <I>Merger-related costs </I>for the third
and fourth quarters of 2002 include pre-integration costs related to our
proposed acquisition of Pharmacia.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">As of January&nbsp;31, 2003, there were approximately 214,810 record holders of
our common stock (symbol PFE).
</FONT>
<P align="right"><FONT size="2"><B>ANNUAL REPORT 2002</B></FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">P 67</FONT>

<P><HR noshade><P>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>Quarterly Consolidated Financial Data (Unaudited)<BR>
PFIZER INC AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B>
</FONT>

<CENTER>
<TABLE cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="66%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

</TABLE>
</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">All financial information reflects our confectionery, shaving and fish-care
products businesses, as well as the femhrt, Loestrin and Estrostep women&#146;s
health product lines, as discontinued operations.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The 2001 data was reclassified to reflect the reclassifications between
<I>Revenues and Costs and expenses </I>as a result of the January&nbsp;1, 2002 adoption
of EITF Issue No.&nbsp;00-25, <I>Vendor Income Statement Characterization of
Consideration Paid to a Reseller of the Vendor&#146;s
Products &#151; </i>codified within
EITF Issue No.&nbsp;01-09, <i>Accounting for Consideration Given by a Vendor to a
Customer.</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">In the second quarter of 2001, we brought the accounting methodology
pertaining to accruals for estimated liabilities related to Medicaid
discounts and contract rebates of Warner-Lambert Company (Warner-Lambert)
into conformity with our historical method. This adjustment increased
revenues in the second quarter of 2001 by $175&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Merger-related costs </I>include transaction, integration and restructuring costs
related to our merger with Warner-Lambert.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">ANNUAL REPORT 2002
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">P 68</FONT>

</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">2001, 2000, 1999 and 1998 data was reclassified to reflect reclassifications
between <I>Revenues and Other costs and expenses </I>of $108&nbsp;million in 2001, $105
million in 2000, $226&nbsp;million in 1999 and $214&nbsp;million in 1998 as a result of
the January&nbsp;1, 2002 adoption of EITF <BR>
Issue No.&nbsp;00-25, <I>Vendor Income Statement
Characterization of Consideration Paid to a Reseller of the Vendor&#146;s Products</I>.
We have not reclassified periods prior to 1998 for EITF Issue No.&nbsp;00-25. After
we reorganized our financial systems due to the merger with Warner-Lambert
Company (Warner-Lambert), the level of detail necessary to develop an EITF
00-25 amount for periods prior to 1998 was no longer available.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">All financial information for 2002, 2001 and 2000 reflects our confectionery,
shaving and fish-care products businesses as well as the femhrt, Loestrin and
Estrostep women&#146;s health product lines as discontinued operations. We have not
restated periods prior to 2000 for these discontinued operations because the
data are not available. After we reorganized our financial systems due to the
merger with Warner-Lambert, the level of detail necessary to develop financial
information for these discontinued operations for periods prior to 2000 was no
longer available. All financial information reflects the previously
discontinued Medical Technology Group (MTG)&nbsp;and Food Science businesses as
discontinued operations.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We have restated all common share and per share data for the 1999
three-for-one stock split.
</FONT>
<P>

<DESCRIPTION>CONSENT OF KPMG LLP
<TEXT>
<PAGE>

                                                                      Exhibit 23


              CONSENT OF INDEPENDENT CERTIFIED PUBLIC ACCOUNTANTS



To the Shareholders and Board of Directors of Pfizer Inc.:

We consent to incorporation herein by reference of our report dated February 27,
2003 on the consolidated balance sheets of Pfizer Inc. and Subsidiary Companies
as of December 31, 2002 and 2001 and the related consolidated statements of
income, shareholders' equity and cash flows for each of the three years in the
period ended December 31, 2002 as contained in the Pfizer Inc. 2002 Annual
Report to Shareholders.  These consolidated financial statements and our report
thereon are incorporated by reference in this Annual Report on Form 10-K for the
year ended December 31, 2002.

We also consent to incorporation by reference of our report in the following
Registration Statements:

- - Form S-8 dated October 27, 1983 (File No. 2-87473),
- - Form S-8 dated March 22, 1990 (File No. 33-34139),
- - Form S-8 dated January 24, 1991 (File No. 33-38708),
- - Form S-8 dated November 18, 1991 (File No. 33-44053),
- - Form S-3 dated May 27, 1993 (File No. 33-49629),
- - Form S-8 dated May 27, 1993 (File No. 33-49631),
- - Form S-8 dated May 19, 1994 (File No. 33-53713),
- - Form S-8 dated October 5, 1994 (File No. 33-55771),
- - Form S-3 dated November 14, 1994 (File No. 33-56435),
- - Form S-8 dated December 20, 1994 (File No. 33-56979),
- - Form S-4 dated February 14, 1995 (File No. 33-57709),
- - Form S-8 dated March 29, 1996 (File No. 33-02061),
- - Form S-8 dated September 25, 1997 (File No. 333-36371),
- - Form S-8 dated April 24, 1998 (File No. 333-50899),
- - Form S-8 dated April 22, 1999 (File No. 333-76839),
- - Form S-4 dated March 9, 2000 (File No. 333-90975),
- - Form S-8 dated June 19, 2000 (File No. 333-90975),
- - Form S-8 dated June 19, 2000 (File No. 333-39606),
- - Form S-8 dated June 19, 2000 (File No. 333-39610),
- - Form S-3 dated October 20, 2000 (File No. 333-48382),
- - Form S-8 dated April 27, 2001 (File No. 333-59660),
- - Form S-8 dated April 27, 2001 (File No. 333-59654),
- - Form S-4 dated October 18, 2002 (File No. 333-98105),
- - Form S-3 dated October 30, 2002 (File No. 333-100853), and
- - Form S-3 dated December 16, 2002 (File No. 33-56435).


KPMG LLP

New York, New York
March 27, 2003

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<P align="right"><FONT size="2">EXHIBIT 99.1</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>Certification by the Chief Executive Officer Pursuant to 18 U. S. C. Section&nbsp;1350,<BR>
as Adopted Pursuant to Section&nbsp;906 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Pursuant to 18 U. S. C. Section&nbsp;1350, I, Henry A. McKinnell, hereby certify
that, to the best of my knowledge, the Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K of Pfizer
Inc. for the fiscal year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 (the &#147;Report&#148;) fully complies
with the requirements of Section&nbsp;13(a) or Section&nbsp;15(d) of the Securities
Exchange Act of 1934, and that the information contained in that Report fairly
presents, in all material respects, the financial condition and results of
operations of Pfizer Inc.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><U>/s/ Henry A. McKinnell</U><BR>
Henry A. McKinnell<BR>
Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer<BR>
March&nbsp;27, 2003
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">This certification accompanies this Report on Form&nbsp;10-K pursuant to Section&nbsp;906
of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 and shall not, except to the extent required
by such Act, be deemed filed by the Company for purposes of Section&nbsp;18 of the
Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
